question: Under what conditions may the Regulator approve the replacement of a Trustee, considering the independence requirements between a Trustee and a Fund Manager?
answer: The Regulator may approve the replacement of a Trustee if it receives a written notice from the Fund Manager indicating the intention to remove the Trustee, along with either a certification that the removal will not negatively impact the Unitholders or the Fund Manager's compliance capabilities, or a Special Resolution from the Unitholders approving the removal and replacement [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2]. Additionally, the replacement Trustee must provide written consent and meet the requirements specified in Section 114(2) of the FSMR [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2]. Furthermore, the Trustee must be independent of the Fund Manager, meaning there should be no shared voting rights, common holding companies, shared directors, shared individuals performing Controlled Functions, or recent professional dealings between the Fund Manager and the Trustee [#TGT:f90dee9e-41b0-46ee-b8ad-8ec88ec8b05c].
source_passage_text: The Regulator may grant approval for the replacement of a Trustee only where it has received: (a) a written notice from the Fund Manager of its intention to remove the Trustee and either: (i) a certification that the removal of the Trustee will not adversely affect the interests of the Unitholders and the Fund Manager's ability to comply with its obligations under the Trust Deed, Prospectus, these Rules and the FSMR; or (ii) a Special Resolution of Unitholders approving the Fund Manager's proposal to remove the Trustee and its replacement with another Trustee; and (b) the written consent of the person who agrees to be the replacement Trustee, and that person meets the requirements for a Trustee in Section 114(2) of the FSMR to be able to act as the replacement Trustee.
target_passage_text: The Trustee of an Investment Trust must be independent of the Fund Manager of that Investment Trust. A Trustee will not be independent of a Fund Manager if— (a) the Fund Manager or the Trustee holds, or exercise voting rights in respect of, any Shares of the other; (b) the Fund Manager and the Trustee have a common holding company or a common ultimate holding company; (c) the Fund Manager or the Trustee have Directors on its Governing Body, who are also Directors of the other; (d) the Fund Manager or the Trustee has individuals performing Controlled Functions who are also individuals performing Controlled Functions for the other; or (e) the Fund Manager and the Trustee have been involved in the previous two years in any professional or material business dealings, other than acting as Fund Manager or Trustee respectively of any other Fund.

question: When the Regulator determines that the Resolution Conditions are met for an Institution, what assumptions must be made regarding Insolvency Proceedings and the Resolution Action for a Difference of Treatment Valuation?
answer: When the Regulator determines that the Resolution Conditions are met for an Institution, it must provide notice of this determination, including the decision and intended actions, to relevant parties such as the Institution and the Board [#TGT:73b31b7c-7d9b-459f-81d4-305aa29ec0a1]. In the context of a Difference of Treatment Valuation, it must be assumed that Insolvency Proceedings would have commenced on the date the Regulator delivered this notice [#SRC:e23b126c-aec2-4c3e-bf47-d59907e3f895]. Additionally, it must be assumed that the Institution would have been fully Wound Up on that date, and that the Resolution Action has not been effected [#SRC:e23b126c-aec2-4c3e-bf47-d59907e3f895].
source_passage_text: A Difference of Treatment Valuation shall (a) assume that Insolvency Proceedings in respect of the Institution in Resolution would have commenced on the date on which the Regulator delivered notice in accordance with section 24(3); (b) assume that the Institution in Resolution would, if it had entered Insolvency Proceedings in accordance with subsection (a), been Wound Up in full on the date on which Insolvency Proceedings in respect of the Institution in Resolution would have commenced; and (c) assume that the Resolution Action has not been effected.
target_passage_text: Where the Regulator determines that the Resolution Conditions are met in relation to an Institution pursuant to subsection ‎(2), the Regulator shall give notice of that determination, the Regulator's decision based on that determination, together with reasons for the decision recorded pursuant to subsection (2) and the actions that the Regulator intends to take as a result of it, as soon as practicable, to the following— (a) the Institution; (b) the Board; (c) where applicable, the supervisory authorities and resolution authorities of the jurisdictions in which any Group Entity or significant Branches are located; and (d) where applicable and necessary, the depositors guarantee schemes to which an Institution is affiliated.

question: Under what circumstances may the Regulator accept a period shorter than three years for an Applicant seeking admission under Rule 2.3.16, and how does this relate to the assets eligibility test requirements?
answer: The Regulator may accept a period shorter than three years for an Applicant if the nature of the Applicant's business or other material considerations justify it, such as when the Issuer has been in operation for less than three years or when the Applicant is a Mining Exploration Reporting Entity or Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity seeking admission under Rule 2.3.16 [#SRC:8fb095d0-bfce-45ac-a53f-504c4c5e14e1]. This is relevant to the assets eligibility test, which the Applicant must satisfy to meet the requirements for admission [#TGT:86469cd3-cfcc-448c-b4e2-e50bf2d32f91].
source_passage_text: The Regulator would accept a shorter period than three years depending on the nature of the Applicant's business and any other material considerations, for example, where the Issuer has been in operation for less than three years, or where the Applicant is a Mining Exploration Reporting Entity or Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity and is seeking admission under Rule 2.3.16 (assets eligibility test).
target_passage_text: Asset eligibility test. In order to meet the assets eligibility test, an Applicant must satisfy the following requirements.

question: Under what circumstances may the Regulator publish a decision notice, final notice, or any other notice, and what information must be included if a person refers a decision to the Appeals Panel?
answer: The Regulator has the discretion to publish a decision notice, final notice, or any other notice related to the exercise of its powers, excluding warning notices [#TGT:de87bb07-107e-4bc3-a834-8f7457702841]. If a person exercises their right to refer a decision to the Appeals Panel, the Regulator will publish appropriate information about that decision, including the notice itself [#SRC:9ddabd85-89c9-44a4-a291-0388531f1314].
source_passage_text: Under section 252(3) of FSMR, we have the discretion to publish a decision notice, final notice or any other notice in relation to the exercise of our powers (other than a warning notice), and details about the matter to which the notice relates. Therefore, if a person exercises their right to refer a decision to the Appeals Panel, we will publish appropriate information about that decision, including the notice itself.
target_passage_text: A decision notice, final notice or any other notice in relation to the exercise of the Regulator's powers (other than a warning notice), and details about the matter to which such notice relates, may be published by the Regulator at its discretion.

question: What obligations does an Issuer have when making an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, and what actions can the Regulator take if these obligations are not met?
answer: An Issuer making an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM is required to publish a Prospectus as part of the regulatory requirements outlined in Sections 58 to 71 of FSMR and Chapter 4 of the Markets Rules (MKT) [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd]. If the Issuer fails to publish the required information in the Prospectus, the Regulator has the authority to publish the information themselves in the manner prescribed by the Rules [#TGT:cd1d6043-c316-4559-ad75-ad86cdaeaa9f]. This ensures that the necessary information is made available to the public, maintaining transparency and compliance with the regulatory framework.
source_passage_text: Regulatory treatment of tokens deemed to be Securities. The requirements for Offers of Securities fall under Sections 58 to 71 of FSMR and Chapter 4 of the Markets Rules (MKT). When an Issuer wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, these requirements include, for example, the obligation to publish a Prospectus under Section 61 of FSMR.
target_passage_text: Prospectus requirement. Regulator power to publish information Where a person making a Prospectus Offer fails to publish any information which that person is required to publish by or under these Regulations, the Regulator may publish such information in the manner prescribed in the Rules.

question: What are the notification requirements for a Person referred to in Rule 3.7.2 when a notifiable interest in a Listed Fund arises or changes, and how is a notifiable interest defined?
answer: A Person referred to in Rule 3.7.2 must notify the other members of the Governing Body within five Business Days when a notifiable interest arises or changes [#SRC:6786cba0-c996-4e15-b9a7-84ae5417cab9]. A notifiable interest is defined as any interest a member of the Governing Body of a Listed Fund has through direct or indirect ownership, beneficial ownership of Units, or any financial or commercial arrangement related to the Listed Fund [#TGT:f46130c3-20bf-4c61-b32d-f638950b9c65].
source_passage_text: A notice relating to a notifiable interest must, subject only to (2), be given by a Person referred to in Rule 3.7.2 to the other members of the Governing Body within five Business Days of the notifiable interest arising or changing.
target_passage_text: Definition of a notifiable interest. A member of the Governing Body of a Listed Fund has a notifiable interest in the Listed Fund if that Person has any interest arising through: (1) the direct or indirect ownership of, or beneficial ownership of, Units of the Listed Fund; or (2) any involvement in financial or commercial arrangement with or relating to the Listed Fund.

question: How should an Authorised Person, who has been granted a Financial Service Permission for multiple Regulated Activities, manage the payment of supervision fees, considering both the highest fee requirement and the timing for annual fee payments?
answer: An Authorised Person with a Financial Service Permission for multiple Regulated Activities must pay the highest supervision fee associated with those activities [#SRC:f63a38e6-be52-4208-83e6-f2ffca7eeaf6]. Additionally, each extra Regulated Activity incurs an annual supervision fee of the lesser of $10,000 or the specific activity's fee [#SRC:f63a38e6-be52-4208-83e6-f2ffca7eeaf6]. The initial annual fee must be paid in full within twenty days of its due date, prorated for the remainder of the year [#TGT:b8f50488-8fd2-4f32-a6c6-d841b3c60c37]. Subsequent annual fees for the period starting 1 January must be paid in advance by 31 January of the relevant year [#TGT:b8f50488-8fd2-4f32-a6c6-d841b3c60c37].
source_passage_text: An Authorised Person which has been granted a Financial Service Permission enabling it to undertake multiple Regulated Activities must pay the highest of the relevant supervision fees associated with such Regulated Activities under these Rules. Each additional Regulated Activity applied for shall incur an additional annual supervision fee of the lesser of $10,000 or the supervision fee associated with such Regulated Activity. Where a Financial Service Permission has been amended to allow the Authorised Person to conduct one or more additional Regulated Activities, the additional supervision fees described in this Rule are payable in accordance with Rule 1.2.2.
target_passage_text: In regard to fees payable on an annual basis pursuant to these Rules: (a) the initial annual fee must be paid in full to the Regulator within twenty days of the date on which the fee becomes due, prorated for the remainder of the calendar year; and (b) subsequent annual fees for the period commencing 1 January are payable in advance and must be paid in full to the Regulator on or before 31 January of the calendar year to which the fee relates.

question: What actions must a Fund Manager take if an Exempt Fund no longer meets the conditions of Rule 3.3.3, and how do the criteria for a Domestic Fund being classified as an Exempt Fund influence these actions?
answer: If an Exempt Fund can no longer meet the conditions set out in Rule 3.3.3, the Fund Manager is obligated to apply for the winding up of the Fund under Section 112 of the FSMR [#SRC:6e2b3cea-7166-4cff-a20a-f10f87ba8b03]. Alternatively, the Fund Manager may choose to reclassify the Fund as a Public Fund, which requires compliance with specific requirements for that classification [#SRC:6e2b3cea-7166-4cff-a20a-f10f87ba8b03]. The criteria for a Domestic Fund to be classified as an Exempt Fund include offering Units only via private placement, ensuring all Unitholders qualify as Professional Clients, and requiring an initial subscription of at least US$50,000 [#TGT:739bcd07-b23a-4057-98eb-1f81fab280f8]. If these criteria are not met, the Fund cannot maintain its Exempt Fund status, prompting the need for reclassification or winding up [#SRC:6e2b3cea-7166-4cff-a20a-f10f87ba8b03].
source_passage_text: If an Exempt Fund can no longer meet the relevant conditions set out in Rule 3.3.3 to be classified as an Exempt Fund, the Fund Manager of that Fund is required, under Section 112 of the FSMR, to apply for the winding up of that Fund. Alternatively, the Fund Manager may have that Fund moved to the classification of a Public Fund, which requires the satisfaction of the requirements and formalities specific to that type of Fund. An Exempt Fund may also, if it wishes to, convert to a Qualified Investor Fund provided it meets the conditions applicable to a Qualified Investor Fund in Rule 3.3.4.
target_passage_text: A Domestic Fund is an Exempt Fund, if: (a) its Units are offered to persons only by way of a private placement; (b) all its Unitholders are persons who meet the criteria to be classified as Professional Clients; and (c) the initial subscription to be paid by a person to become a Unitholder is at least US$50,000, and it does not satisfy the conditions in Rule ‎3.3.4 below to be a Qualified Investor Fund.

question: If an Authorised Person doesn't meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, what must they do before making certain payments, and how does this relate to the maximum distributable amount?
answer: An Authorised Person that does not meet the Combined Buffer Requirement must first calculate the maximum distributable amount and notify the Regulator before making payments like distributions on CET1 Capital or on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e]. Once this is done, they must ensure that any distributions do not exceed this calculated amount, as required by Rule 3.19.3(b) [#SRC:27f9bf56-82e3-4122-9d99-41e44b5fee9e].
source_passage_text: Restrictions on distributions. An Authorised Person must: (a) in subsequently taking any of the actions described in Rule 3.19.3(b)(i) and (ii), after having calculated the maximum distributable amount and notified the Regulator, ensure that it distributes no more than its calculated maximum distributable amount; and (b) prepare and submit a capital conservation plan pursuant to Rule 3.19.9.
target_passage_text: Restrictions on distributions. Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must: (a) calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with Rule 3.19.6; and (b) ensure that it does not undertake any of the following actions until such time as it has calculated the maximum distributable amount and notified the Regulator under Rule 3.19.7: (i) make a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital, or create an obligation to pay variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, or pay variable remuneration if the obligation to pay was created at a time when the institution failed to meet its Combined Buffer Requirement; or (ii) make payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments.

question: What must a Mining Reporting Entity include when sharing forecast financial information, and how does this connect to the rules for sharing Ore Reserves details?
answer: When sharing forecast financial information, a Mining Reporting Entity must include all important economic assumptions, and if these are sensitive, they must explain how they determined these assumptions [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. They also need to include other important assumptions and the Production Target [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. This connects to the rules for Ore Reserves, which require sharing key details like mining and metallurgical factors, cut-off parameters, and the accuracy of the estimates [#TGT:cb1ec09f-a7d3-4c38-ba2e-4e72ed8c3129]. Both sets of information help give a full picture of the entity's plans and estimates.
source_passage_text: A Mining Reporting Entitys disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include: (1) in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information: (a) all material economic assumptions employed; (b) if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and Guidance A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure. (c) all other material assumptions utilised. (2) the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_passage_text: ORE RESERVES . Rule 11.6 also requires that when a Mining Reporting Entity discloses an estimate of Ore Reserves, the disclosure is also to include key information relating to mining (recovery/dilution) factors or assumptions, metallurgical factors or assumptions, cut-off parameters, study status and the relative accuracy/confidence.

question: When does the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement not apply to green assets, and what role does an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark play?
answer: The Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement does not apply to green assets if they are part of or follow an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark [#SRC:9c6ac3b6-ffca-4e6e-a0d2-7252f3e4be86]. A green asset is eligible if it is seen as environmentally sustainable under one Acceptable Green Taxonomy or if it is included in or tracks an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark [#TGT:d2c4557a-05a9-47ae-90b5-b819cedfd9de]. Therefore, being part of such a benchmark means the attestation requirement is not needed.
source_passage_text: Under Rule 3.8.6, the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement does not apply to Eligible Green Portfolio Assets which are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark in accordance with Rule 3.8.4(b).
target_passage_text: An asset is an Eligible Green Portfolio Asset if it is: (a) considered environmentally sustainable or equivalent under an Acceptable Green Taxonomy, provided that only one Acceptable Green Taxonomy is used by an ADGM Green Portfolio; or (b) included in or otherwise tracks an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark.

question: Under what conditions may the Regulator disqualify an auditor or actuary from acting for an Authorised Person, Recognised Body, or Reporting Entity, and how does the seriousness of a contravention influence this decision?
answer: The Regulator may disqualify an auditor or actuary if it determines that there has been a contravention of the Regulations [#TGT:5cca9150-8e16-41b4-a5ef-74950916d06e]. In making this decision, the Regulator will consider the nature and seriousness of the contravention and its effects, such as potential loss to customers, damage to the ADGM's reputation, or increased risk of financial crime [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22].
source_passage_text: In deciding whether to exercise our power to disqualify an auditor or actuary under section 233(3) of FSMR, and what the scope of any disqualification will be, we will take into account all the circumstances of the case, including: (a) the nature and seriousness of any contravention of FSMR or Rules and the effect of that contravention; (b) whether any contravention of FSMR or Rules, or any failure to disclose information to us, has resulted in or is likely to result in: (i) loss to customers; (ii) damage to the reputation of the ADGM; or (iii) an increased risk that a firm, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity may be used for the purposes of financial crime; (c) any action taken by the auditor or actuary to remedy the contravention; (d) any disciplinary action taken (or to be taken) against the auditor or actuary by a relevant professional body, and whether that action adequately addresses the particular contravention; and (e) the previous compliance record of the auditor or actuary concerned, and whether the relevant regulatory body or professional body has imposed any previous disciplinary sanctions that may be relevant.
target_passage_text: If the Regulator considers that an auditor or actuary has committed a contravention of these Regulations, it may disqualify the auditor or actuary from being the auditor of, or (as the case may be), from acting as an actuary for, any Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity or any particular class thereof.

question: What are the obligations of a Third Party Provider regarding the availability and accessibility of information related to dispute resolution services and the Governing Contract?
answer: A Third Party Provider is required to ensure that information about dispute resolution services is made available to the Customer in a clear, comprehensive, and easily accessible form [#TGT:08650621-06b8-481f-8650-2c5ebdb06be0]. Additionally, the information specified under Rule 20.13.3 must be available on the website of the Third Party Provider, at its main office and branches, and included in the general terms and conditions of the Governing Contract [#SRC:055fc91a-22c6-4511-9508-b90212a4d414].
source_passage_text: The information to be made available under Rule 20.13.3 must be made available: (a) on the website of the Third Party Provider; (b) at the main office and any branches of the Third Party Provider; and (c) in the general terms and conditions of the Governing Contract.
target_passage_text: A Third Party Provider must make available to the Customer the details of the dispute resolution services able to deal with disputes concerning the rights and obligations arising under this Chapter in a clear, comprehensive and easily accessible form.

question: When can an Issuer offer Securities to 200 people who aren't Professional Clients on a Multilateral Trading Facility, and how does this fit with the FSMR's rules?
answer: An Issuer can offer Securities to up to 200 people who aren't Professional Clients on a Multilateral Trading Facility (MTF) under MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42]. This fits with the FSMR's rules, which allow such an Offer if it's directed at no more than 200 non-Professional Clients or Market Counterparties, and the Securities are offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc].
source_passage_text: MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) provides for the specific circumstance where an Exempt Offer can be directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients, where the Securities are to be admitted to trading on a MTF. An Issuer seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF in accordance with MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) may also, pursuant to MKT Rule 4.3.3, utilise an Exempt Offer that relies on one or more of the circumstances within MKT Rule 4.3.1, with the exception of MKT Rule 4.3.1(2). For example, an Issuer may make a simultaneous Exempt Offer to 200 Persons under MKT rule 4.3.1(13), and an unlimited number of Professional Clients under MKT Rule 4.3.1(1).
target_passage_text: For the purposes of section 61(3)(a) of the FSMR, the Regulator prescribes the following to be circumstances in which an Offer is an Exempt Offer: (1) an Offer made to or directed at only Professional Clients; (2) an Offer in or from the ADGM which is directed at no more than 50 Persons in any 12-month period, excluding Professional Clients who are not natural persons; (3) an Offer where the total consideration to be paid by a Person to acquire the Securities is at least $100,000, or an equivalent amount in another currency; (4) an Offer where the Securities are denominated in amounts of at least $100,000, or an equivalent amount in another currency; (5) an Offer where the total aggregate consideration for the Securities offered is less than $100,000, or an equivalent amount in another currency, calculated over a period of 12 months; (6) an Offer where Shares are issued in substitution for Shares of the same class as already issued, where the issue of the new Shares does not involve any increase in the issued Share capital; (7) an Offer where the Securities are Convertibles issued under a Prospectus to existing members or creditors of the Issuer or a member of its Group and there is no additional consideration to be paid; (8) an Offer where the Securities are offered in connection with a Takeover and a document is made available containing information which is considered by the Regulator as being equivalent to that of a Prospectus; (9) an Offer where the Securities are offered, allotted or to be allotted in connection with a merger if a document is available containing information which is regarded by the Regulator as being equivalent to that of a Prospectus; (10) an Offer where the Securities are offered, allotted or to be allotted in connection with a rights issue where: (a) the Securities are of a class subject to Reporting Entity disclosure; and (b) a document is made available containing information on the number and nature of the Securities including rights attaching to those Securities and the reasons for and details of the Offer; (11) an Offer where the Shares are offered, allotted or to be allotted to existing Shareholders free of charge or dividends paid out in the form of Shares of the same class as the Shares in respect of which the dividends are paid, and a document is made available containing information on the number and nature of the Shares and the reasons for and details of the Offer; (12) an Offer where the Securities are offered, allotted or to be allotted to an existing or former Director or Employee, or any Close Relative of such a Director or Employee, of the Issuer or a member of the same Group as the Issuer and: (a) the Issuer or the member of the Group already has its Securities admitted to trading on a Regulated Exchange; and (b) a document is made available to the offerees containing information on the number and nature of the Securities and the reasons for and details of the Offer; or (13) other than in relation to Debentures and Sukuk, an Offer in or from the ADGM which is directed at no more than 200 Persons that are not Professional Clients or Market Counterparties, in circumstances where the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility.

question: Under what conditions does dealing by a market maker not contravene section 92(2) regarding insider dealing, and how does this relate to the behavior of an Insider dealing in financial instruments based on inside information?
answer: Dealing by a market maker does not contravene section 92(2) if it is undertaken solely in the course of the legitimate performance of their functions on their own account [#SRC:82586828-a155-4b3d-9f47-5207f5828538]. This exemption is relevant when considering the behavior of an Insider who deals in financial instruments based on inside information, as such behavior would typically constitute insider dealing unless it falls under specific exceptions like market making [#TGT:da3ba0b9-ff62-4830-a771-93c35b02af25].
source_passage_text: Market making. Dealing undertaken by a person solely in the course of the legitimate performance of his functions as a market maker on his own account will not contravene section 92(2) (Insider Dealing).
target_passage_text: The first type of Behaviour is where an Insider deals, or attempts to deal, in a Financial Instrument, Related Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity on the basis of Inside Information relating to the Financial Instruments, Related Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities in question.

question: When don't the APP 7 rules apply to an Applicant or a Listed Entity?
answer: The APP 7 rules don't apply to an Applicant if Rule 9.6.2 says they don't have to follow these restrictions [#SRC:d1edac54-b7c2-4022-81ed-d1385cc550a4]. For a Listed Entity, the Regulator might decide the rules don't apply if the entity qualifies for the Official List, has a good profit or revenue record, or has valuable tangible assets [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac].
source_passage_text: Rules 2.3.16(7)(a) and (b) do not apply if under Rule 9.6.2 the Applicant is not required to apply the restrictions in APP 7.
target_passage_text: Entry into Restriction Agreements and Application of Restriction. Unless the Regulator decides otherwise, the restrictions in categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 do not apply in relation to a Listed Entity that: (1) qualifies for admission to the Official List pursuant to Rule 2.3.15; (2) has a track record of profitability or revenue acceptable to the Regulator; or (3) in the opinion of the Regulator, has tangible assets with a readily ascertainable value which constitute a substantial proportion of the total value of its assets.

question: Who can get Confidential Information from the Regulator, and what might the Regulator require from them?
answer: The Regulator can give Confidential Information to groups like the ADGM Registrar of Companies, other regulators, and law enforcement if it helps with a Public Function and follows the rules [#TGT:c143e65b-358c-4ac8-855c-546a1c91e4d1]. The Regulator might require these groups to agree to certain conditions or limit how they use the information [#SRC:6b15279a-ffe6-4bc9-961d-d8d4a305ef6f].
source_passage_text: As set out in paragraphs 4.1.3 and 4.1.4 above, in disclosing any Confidential Information under section 199(1), the Regulator may require the requesting authority to comply with certain conditions or agree to restrict the uses to which the Confidential Information may be put, insofar as the Regulator considers appropriate.
target_passage_text: Subject to subsection (2), the Regulator may disclose Confidential Information for the purpose of facilitating the carrying out of a Public Function where such disclosure is— (a) permitted or required under any enactment applicable to the Regulator, including, for the avoidance of doubt, any applicable international obligations; (b) made to— (i) the ADGM Registrar of Companies; (ii) a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Regulator; (iii) a governmental or regulatory authority exercising powers and performing functions relating to anti-money laundering, counter terrorist financing or sanctions compliance, whether in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or otherwise; (iv) a self regulatory body or organisation exercising and performing powers and functions in relation to financial services, whether in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or otherwise; (v) a criminal law enforcement agency, whether in the U.A.E or otherwise, for the purpose of any criminal investigation or criminal proceedings; or (vi) a civil law enforcement agency or body, whether in the Abu Dhabi Global Market, U.A.E or otherwise; for the purpose of assisting the performance by any such person of its functions and powers; or (c) made in good faith for the purposes of the exercise of the functions and powers of the Regulator or in order to further the Regulator's objectives.

question: Under what conditions does a Fund Prospectus become an Approved Prospectus according to the FSMR, and how does the Regulator's approval process relate to the requirements prescribed in the Rules?
answer: A Fund Prospectus becomes an Approved Prospectus under the FSMR only if the Regulator issues a notice to the Applicant stating its approval of the Prospectus or Supplementary Prospectus, as applicable [#SRC:e4f01dc3-b9ba-4fbb-a37e-72e4a4dfb5ff]. Additionally, if the Prospectus comprises multiple documents, the Regulator must approve all such documents [#SRC:e4f01dc3-b9ba-4fbb-a37e-72e4a4dfb5ff]. This approval must be in accordance with the requirements prescribed in the Rules, ensuring that the Prospectus meets the necessary standards to be considered an Approved Prospectus [#TGT:caf92348-9f78-4a22-b449-0824165b55e1].
source_passage_text: A Fund Prospectus is not an Approved Prospectus for the purposes of section 61(2) of the FSMR unless the Regulator has issued to the Applicant a notice stating its approval: (a) of the Prospectus or Supplementary Prospectus, as the case may be; and (b) in the case of a Prospectus in (a) comprising multiple documents, of all the multiple documents.
target_passage_text: For the purposes of subsection ‎(1)— (a) a Prospectus is an Approved Prospectus if it is approved by the Regulator in accordance with the requirements prescribed in the Rules; and (b) a reference to a Prospectus made by or under these Regulations is a reference to an Approved Prospectus, unless the context requires otherwise.

question: What must a Recognised Investment Exchange do to make sure transactions are settled on time when using a Clearing Service, especially for Digital Securities?
answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange must have satisfactory arrangements to ensure that transactions are settled on time when using a Clearing Service [#TGT:c56de460-9435-43a8-b170-bfe38c05a616]. These arrangements should cover all aspects of Clearing and settlement, including performance and compromise [#TGT:c56de460-9435-43a8-b170-bfe38c05a616]. For Digital Securities, the FSRA does not allow Remote Clearing Houses, so the exchange must use other methods to comply with MIR Rule 3.8.1 [#SRC:54798d14-a849-4384-81d3-79f14fca8fd4].
source_passage_text: DIGITAL SECURITIES SETTLEMENT Digital Settlement Facilities (DSFs) Pursuant to MIR Rule 3.8.1, RIEs or MTFs are required to have satisfactory arrangements for securing the timely discharge of the rights and liabilities of the parties to transactions taking place on its platform. MIR Rule 3.8.2 normally allows for a RCH or Remote Clearing House (noting the FSRAs position that it will not permit Remote Clearing Houses for this purpose in the context of Digital Securities) to be deemed as sufficient for the purposes of satisfying MIR Rule 3.8.1.

question: How must an Authorised Person determine which capital instruments to include in its Available Stable Funding, considering the exclusion of certain Tier 2 capital instruments?
answer: An Authorised Person must identify its capital instruments for inclusion in Available Stable Funding by evaluating the eligibility of these instruments under specific rules. The instruments must meet the requirements set out in Rule 3.10.2, Rule 3.11.2, and Rule 3.12.2, while excluding all Tier 2 capital instruments with a residual maturity of less than one year [#SRC:28d5816c-6e62-4526-954c-d1c4fa6f17d1]. Tier 2 Capital, as defined, includes capital instruments that meet the eligibility criteria in Rule 3.12.3 and related Share premium accounts [#TGT:2ba8da20-d967-4d1e-bf49-877f5e6ceddb]. Therefore, when determining which instruments to include, the Authorised Person must ensure compliance with these eligibility criteria and exclusions.
source_passage_text: Available Stable Funding (ASF). Subject to Rule A10.4.6, an Authorised Person must identify its capital instruments that are to be included in its Available Stable Funding by considering the capital elements that are meet the requirements for eligibility under: (a) Rule 3.10.2; (b) Rule 3.11.2; and (c) Rule 3.12.2, excluding all Tier 2 capital instruments with residual maturity of less than one year.
target_passage_text: T2 Capital consists of the sum of the following elements: (a) capital instruments which meet the eligibility criteria laid down in Rule 3.12.3; and (b) the Share premium accounts related to the instruments referred to in (a).

question: How does the RegLab framework make sure FinTech Participants protect clients and meet authorisation rules?
answer: The RegLab framework makes sure FinTech Participants protect clients by setting limits on clients and exposure, along with geographical restrictions to control test activities [#SRC:7fae4f73-f02a-415f-88c1-6b1aa4936e19]. To meet authorisation rules, applicants must prove they have enough resources, define test parameters, and propose a reporting schedule [#TGT:40054dfa-768b-4ece-ac91-c15c83f4f16d]. They must also detail safeguards and have an exit strategy for clients, ensuring risks and client impact are managed [#TGT:40054dfa-768b-4ece-ac91-c15c83f4f16d].
source_passage_text: Blank-Sheet Approach . As certain Rules will be waived or modified for the FinTech Participant under the RegLab, the Regulator will, among other things:- (a) set client and exposure limits to limit the scope and scale of the FinTech Participants test activities; and (b) impose boundaries/geographical restrictions to ensure that client impact is controlled and the clients interests are protected. Please refer to section 5.2 below titled Authorisation Requirements for further details of the requirements that the Regulator may impose.
target_passage_text: Authorisation Requirements In order to become authorised under the RegLab framework, the applicant must also demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Regulator that it: (a) satisfies, and will continue to satisfy, any Threshold Conditions made under section 7(2) of the FSMR, including but not limited to the following: i. the applicant has adequate and appropriate resources, including financial resources, to develop and test its FinTech Proposal; ii. the applicant is fit and proper; and iii. the applicant has relevant technical and business knowledge and experience to develop and test the FinTech Proposal; (b) is able to clearly define the FinTech Proposal’s test parameters, control boundaries, key milestones and intended outcomes; (c) is able to propose an acceptable reporting schedule to report to the Regulator on the status and progress of development and testing of its FinTech Proposal; (d) is able to satisfactorily detail the safeguards that have been put in place, and demonstrate how they are appropriate to the FinTech Proposal being tested, the risks that are posed and the type of clients that are likely to be affected by the proposed innovation; (e) is able to set out a fair and proper exit strategy for clients should the FinTech Proposal be discontinued, completed or deployed on a broader scale outside the RegLab; and (f) is able to satisfy all applicable ADGM Regulations, Rules, conditions and/or limitations that the Regulator may prescribe.

question: Under what circumstances does the FSMR consider the disclosure of Inside Information by an Insider to be Market Abuse, and how does this align with the definition provided in the second instance of the related regulatory text?
answer: The FSMR considers the disclosure of Inside Information by an Insider to be Market Abuse when the disclosure occurs outside the proper course of the Insider's employment, profession, or duties [#SRC:2099b5f8-78a0-43e7-8fc5-0295f590463e]. This aligns with the definition provided in the second instance of the related regulatory text, which similarly identifies such disclosures as improper when they are not part of the Insider's legitimate professional activities [#TGT:24c9495c-026d-446e-865a-9051fa94f13b]. Both texts emphasize the importance of the context in which the information is disclosed, focusing on whether the action falls within the scope of the Insider's official responsibilities.
source_passage_text: Section 92(3) of the FSMR provides that Market Abuse will constitute instances where: "...an Insider discloses Inside Information to another person otherwise than in the proper course of the exercise of his employment, profession or duties."
target_passage_text: The second is where an Insider discloses Inside Information to another person otherwise than in the proper course of the exercise of his employment, profession or duties.

question: What are the obligations of a Recognised Investment Exchange regarding the public disclosure of transactions in Financial Instruments, and how must these disclosures incorporate post-trade information such as trading day and time?
answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange is required to make public specific details about transactions in Financial Instruments that are either admitted to trading on or concluded within their systems. These details include those specified in Rule 3.6.7, indications of trades determined by factors other than current market valuation, and any amendments to previously disclosed information [#SRC:5f815122-ada4-4ada-9311-f869cdb31386]. In addition, the public disclosure must incorporate post-trade information such as the trading day and time, which must be specified in UTC or a clearly identified time zone [#TGT:26773b68-1f2d-4ec2-9bde-0271968ad33a]. This ensures transparency and consistency in the reporting of transaction details.
source_passage_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange shall, with regard to Transactions in respect of Financial Instruments admitted to trading on or concluded within their systems, make public the following details: (a) those specified in Rule 3.6.7; (b) an indication that the exchange of Financial Instruments is determined by factors other than the current market valuation of the Financial Instrument, where the Transaction: (i) related to an individual Financial Instrument in a portfolio trade; or (ii) is a volume weighted average price Transaction. (c) an indication that the trade was a negotiated trade, where applicable; and (d) any amendments to previously disclosed information, where applicable. These details shall be made public either by reference to each Transaction or in a form aggregating the volume and price of all Transactions in the same Financial Instrument taking place at the same price at the same time.
target_passage_text: Deferrals. Post-trade information: /Table Start Detail Information (a) Trading Day The trading day on which the transaction was executed. (b) Trading Time The time in UTC (Universal Time Coordinated) or a time zone clearly identified to the user at which the transaction was executed. (c) Instrument Identification This shall consist of a unique code to be decided by the Regulator identifying the Financial Instrument which is the subject of the transaction; or, if the Financial Instrument in question does not have a unique identification code, the report must include the name of the Financial Instrument. (d) Unit Price The price per Financial Instrument excluding commission and (where relevant) accrued interest. (e) Price Notation The currency in which the price is expressed. (f) Quantity The number of units of the Financial Instruments. (g) Venue identification Identification, if applicable, of the venue where the transaction was executed. /Table End

question: What are the obligations of an Authorised Person regarding informing the Regulator about material outsourcing arrangements, and how does the potential risk exposure from outsourcing influence these obligations?
answer: An Authorised Person is required to inform the Regulator about any material outsourcing arrangements [#TGT:2222146c-60fc-432c-948b-398a77963409]. This obligation is crucial because outsourcing, while beneficial for efficiency and cost reduction, can expose the firm to additional risks [#SRC:d6a3304f-22d5-4dd8-b291-3aaa66728880]. Therefore, it is imperative for the Authorised Person to supervise outsourced activities carefully to manage these risks effectively [#SRC:d6a3304f-22d5-4dd8-b291-3aaa66728880].
source_passage_text: Financial firms frequently decide to outsource aspects of their operations to other parties, Related or not. Outsourcing can bring significant benefits to a firm in terms of efficiency, cost reduction and risk management. However, both the process of implementing outsourcing arrangements and the outsourcing relationship itself may expose a firm to additional risk. It is therefore important that firms take care to supervise the conduct of activities that are outsourced. GEN 3.3.32(1) requires an Authorised Person to inform the Regulator about any material outsourcing arrangement.
target_passage_text: Outsourcing: An Authorised Person must inform the Regulator about any material outsourcing arrangements.

question: How must an Authorised Person manage the disclosure of conflicts of interest when preparing or publishing Investment Research, considering the requirements of Rule 6.4.2 and Rule 3.3.23?
answer: An Authorised Person is required to manage conflicts of interest by taking reasonable steps to identify and either prevent or manage them, as outlined in Rule 6.4.2 [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]. When preparing or publishing Investment Research, the Authorised Person must ensure that any disclosure of conflicts of interest is made in a durable medium and includes sufficient detail. This detail must be adequate for the Client to make an informed decision regarding the service in which the conflict arises, as specified in Rule 3.3.23 [#TGT:448d19a7-728b-491f-9eb2-284dc92112e9].
source_passage_text: The requirements in this Rule 6.4.2 apply to an Authorised Person in addition to other requirements under FSMR and any rules made thereunder. For example, an Authorised Person is required to take reasonable steps to identify actual or potential conflicts of interest and then prevent or manage them under GEN 3.3.21-3.3.24. An Authorised Person must also have adequate procedures and controls when it prepares or publishes Investment Research.
target_passage_text: Conflicts of Interest: The disclosure in Rule ‎3.3.23 must: (1) be made in a durable medium; and (2) include sufficient detail, taking into account the nature of the Client, to enable that Client to take an informed decision with respect to the service in the context of which the conflict of interest arises.

question: If an Authorised Person wants to use financial Collateral under the FCCA, what must they do to recognise CRM effects, and what types of Collateral are eligible?
answer: To recognise the effects of Credit Risk Mitigation (CRM) when using financial Collateral under the FCCA, an Authorised Person must comply with the requirements in Rule 4.13.8 [#SRC:c36bf3cf-160f-43ab-bb40-9d7f5ceec7b8]. Eligible financial Collateral includes instruments listed in Rule 4.13.5, equity Securities traded on a regulated exchange, and Units in a Collective Investment Fund that invests mainly in such equity Securities [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85]. The Fund's Units must have a daily quoted price, and a large portion of the Fund's property must be invested in eligible instruments [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85].
source_passage_text: Collateral In order to recognise the effects of CRM of the types of Collateral set out in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7, an Authorised Person must ensure that the relevant requirements in Rule 4.13.8 are complied with.
target_passage_text: For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral comprises: (a) any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5; (b) any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange; and (c) any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund which invests in equity Securities referred to in (b), where: (i) a price for the Units is publicly quoted daily; and (ii) at least 90% of the deposited property of the Fund is invested in instruments listed in this Rule and Rule 4.13.5.

question: Under what circumstances may the Regulator impose a supplementary fee on an Authorised Person with a branch conducting Regulated Activities outside ADGM, and how is the annual supervision fee determined for such a branch?
answer: The Regulator may impose a supplementary fee on an Authorised Person if the branch operates in a jurisdiction where there is no adequate memorandum of understanding between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92]. Additionally, the Authorised Person must pay an annual supervision fee to the Regulator, which is calculated as 50% of the highest annual supervision fee for the Regulated Activities conducted from the branch [#TGT:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c].
source_passage_text: The Regulator may charge a supplementary fee in addition to the fees specified in Rule 7.1.1 and 7.1.2 where the proposed branch would operate in a jurisdiction where there is no adequate memorandum of understanding in place between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator in that jurisdiction.
target_passage_text: An Authorised Person that has established a branch outside ADGM from which it conducts Regulated Activities must pay to the Regulator an annual supervision fee equal to 50% of the highest annual supervision fee for those Regulated Activities it undertakes from the branch. The initial supervision fee due shall be prorated and paid in accordance with Rule 1.2.2(a).

question: When does a Reporting Entity need to follow Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i) if a Listed Entity is admitted under the assets eligibility test?
answer: A Reporting Entity needs to follow Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i) if a Listed Entity is admitted under the assets eligibility test and has less than three years of audited financial statements, or if the Regulator decides it's necessary for other reasons, like a cash-box admission [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8]. The assets eligibility test has its own set of requirements that an Applicant must satisfy, though these are not specified here [#TGT:86469cd3-cfcc-448c-b4e2-e50bf2d32f91].
source_passage_text: The Regulator will generally require a Reporting Entity to comply with Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i) in circumstances where the Listed Entity with Securities being admitted to the Official List is admitted under the assets eligibility test (see Rule 2.3.16), has less than three years of audited financial statements as prescribed in Rule 2.3.2(1), or is considered by the Regulator, for other reasons, to require quarterly cash reports, such as the admission of a cash-box.
target_passage_text: Asset eligibility test. In order to meet the assets eligibility test, an Applicant must satisfy the following requirements.

question: Under what conditions must a Listed Entity ensure the admission of Securities resulting from the conversion of Convertible Securities becomes effective, and what role does the Regulator play in this process?
answer: A Listed Entity must ensure that the admission of Securities resulting from the conversion of Convertible Securities becomes effective by adhering to specific conditions. The Convertible Securities must have been issued either before the Listed Entity's Securities were admitted to the Official List, with disclosure of their existence and material terms in an Approved Prospectus or documents lodged with the Regulator under Rule 2.4.3, or after admission, in compliance with the Rules [#SRC:e6d38e81-0c51-4259-b948-7918e7538709]. The Regulator's role is crucial, as the admission of these Securities to the Official List becomes effective only when the Regulator publishes the admission by adding the Securities to the Official List on the ADGM website [#TGT:d28d3376-4af3-4b11-b90d-3f24c8e54555].
source_passage_text: An issue of Securities as a result of the conversion of Convertible Securities. The Listed Entity must have issued the Convertible Securities: (a) before its Securities were admitted to the Official List, and disclosed the existence and material terms of the Convertible Securities in its Approved Prospectus or documents lodged with the Regulator under Rule 2.4.3; or (b) after its Securities were admitted to the Official List, and complied with the Rules when it did so.
target_passage_text: Listing application. An admission of Securities to the Official List becomes effective only when the Regulator has published the admission by adding such Securities to the Official List on the ADGM website.

question: Who counts as an Insider if they have Inside Information because of their role or capital holding, and what if they got the information through crime?
answer: An Insider is someone with Inside Information due to their role in a management or supervisory body, or because they hold capital, for both a Reporting Entity and an Issuer of Financial Instruments [#TGT:7968fd15-b5dd-45db-a02c-a941c690df86]. The SOURCE text only mentions Issuers of Financial Instruments, not Reporting Entities, showing a smaller focus [#SRC:927dee34-d53d-4ff7-90ef-042863f93509]. If someone gets Inside Information through crime, both texts agree they are Insiders, highlighting how the information is obtained [#SRC:927dee34-d53d-4ff7-90ef-042863f93509][#TGT:7968fd15-b5dd-45db-a02c-a941c690df86].
source_passage_text: The term "Insider" is defined in section 94 as meaning: "...any person who has Inside Information: (a) as a result of his membership of an administrative, management or supervisory body of an Issuer of Financial Instruments; (b) as a result of his holding in the capital of an Issuer of Financial Instruments; (c) as a result of having access to the information through the exercise of his employment, profession or duties; (d) as a result of his criminal activities; or (e) which he has obtained by other means and which he knows, or could reasonably be expected to know, is Inside Information."
target_passage_text: Insiders For the purposes of this Part, an Insider is any person who has Inside Information— (a) as a result of his membership of an administrative, management or supervisory body of a Reporting Entity or an Issuer of Financial Instruments; (b) as a result of his holding in the capital of a Reporting Entity or an Issuer of Financial Instruments; (c) as a result of having access to the information through the exercise of his employment, profession or duties; (d) as a result of his criminal activities; or (e) which he has obtained by other means and which he knows, or could reasonably be expected to know, is Inside Information.

question: How must an Authorised Person ensure compliance with the requirements for recognising CRM effects of Collateral under Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7, particularly when dealing with Counterparty Risk Exposures from an SFT included in the Trading Book?
answer: An Authorised Person must comply with the relevant requirements in Rule 4.13.8 to recognise the effects of CRM for the types of Collateral specified in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7 [#SRC:c36bf3cf-160f-43ab-bb40-9d7f5ceec7b8]. When these exposures arise from a Securities Financing Transaction (SFT) included in the Trading Book, the eligible financial Collateral encompasses all instruments that may be included in the Trading Book [#TGT:cacd95d6-558b-4d84-93f1-e1d5664a1d01]. Thus, the Authorised Person must ensure that both the compliance with Rule 4.13.8 and the inclusion of eligible financial instruments in the Trading Book are addressed.
source_passage_text: Collateral In order to recognise the effects of CRM of the types of Collateral set out in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7, an Authorised Person must ensure that the relevant requirements in Rule 4.13.8 are complied with.
target_passage_text: In the case of any Counterparty Risk Exposures in Rules 4.13.5 and 4.13.6 arising from an SFT which are included in the Trading Book, eligible financial Collateral includes all instruments which an Authorised Person may include in its Trading Book.

question: How does the Regulator check if a document has all the needed information for Exempt Securities, like those offered in a merger?
answer: The Regulator checks if a document has all the needed information for Exempt Securities by looking at what is required under Part 6 of the FSMR and the Rules in the chapter [#SRC:28df1695-9376-47bf-921d-e9cbd61c7b30]. For Securities offered in a merger, the document must have information that is similar to a Prospectus [#TGT:16a48ee7-becd-40f8-8af0-17dbcd09dfc0]. This ensures the document meets the necessary standards.
source_passage_text: In considering whether a document referred to in Rule 4.4.1(3) or (4) contains all the relevant information, the Regulator will take into account the information required under Part 6 of the FSMR and the Rules in this chapter.
target_passage_text: For the purposes of section 61(3)(b) of the FSMR the Regulator hereby prescribes the types of Securities that are Exempt Securities: (1) Shares representing, over a period of 12 months, less than 10% of the number of Shares of the same class already admitted to trading on the same Recognised Investment Exchange; (2) Shares issued in substitution for Shares of the same class already admitted to trading on the same Recognised Investment Exchange, if the issue of the Shares does not involve any increase in the issued capital; (3) Securities offered in connection with a Takeover Offer, if a document is available containing information which is regarded by the Regulator as being equivalent to that of a Prospectus; (4) Securities offered, allotted or to be allotted in connection with a merger, if a document is available containing information which is regarded by the Regulator as being equivalent to that of the Prospectus; (5) Securities offered, allotted or to be allotted in connection with a rights issue if: (a) the Securities are of the same class as the Securities already admitted to trading on the same Recognised Investment Exchange; and (b) a document is made available containing information on the number and nature of the Securities and the reasons for and details of the Offer; (6) Shares offered, allotted or to be allotted to existing Shareholders free of charge, or in respect of dividends paid out in the form of Shares of the same class as the Shares in respect of which the dividends are paid, if: (a) the Shares are of the same class as the Shares already admitted to trading on the same Recognised Investment Exchange; and (b) a document is made available containing information on the number and nature of the Shares and the reasons for and details of the Offer; (7) Securities offered, allotted or to be allotted to an existing or former Director or Employee, or any Close Relative of such a Director or Employee, of the Issuer or a member of the same Group as the Issuer and if: (a) the Securities are of the same class as the Securities already admitted to trading on the same Recognised Investment Exchange; and (b) a document is made available containing information on the number and nature of the Securities and the reasons for and detail of the Offer; (8) Shares resulting from the conversion or exchange of other Securities or from the exercise of the rights conferred by other Securities, if the Shares are of the same class as the Shares already admitted to trading on the same Recognised Investment Exchange; or (9) Securities already admitted to trading on another Recognised Investment Exchange or Regulated Exchange (the "Other Market"), where: (a) the Securities, or Securities of the same class, have been admitted to trading and continuously traded on the Other Market for more than 18 months; (b) the on-going obligations for trading on that Other Market have been complied with; and (c) the Person requesting the admission to trading of the Securities under this exemption makes a summary document in the English language which is approved by the Regulator in accordance with the requirements in section 4.6 and published: (i) containing the information set out in Rule 4.5.2(1)(b); (ii) stating where the most recent and current Prospectus, if any, can be obtained; and (iii) specifying where the financial information disclosed by the Issuer pursuant to its on-going disclosure obligations of the Other Market is available. (10) Securities offered in connection with any issue of Securities under Rules 9.7.1 or 9.7.4, where the Securities are of the same class already admitted to trading on the same Recognised Investment Exchange.

question: Under what conditions does the engagement of a Recognised Clearing House or Remote Clearing House satisfy Rule 3.8.1, and what obligations does a Recognised Investment Exchange have when engaging a Clearing Service to ensure timely discharge of transaction-related rights and liabilities?
answer: The engagement of a Recognised Clearing House or Remote Clearing House is considered sufficient to satisfy Rule 3.8.1 [#SRC:9217cc24-dbcc-43e5-8884-f398ee26b820]. However, when a Recognised Investment Exchange engages a Clearing Service, it must ensure that satisfactory arrangements are in place for the timely discharge of rights and liabilities related to transactions effected on the exchange. This includes ensuring that these rights and liabilities are cleared and settled through performance, compromise, or other means [#TGT:c56de460-9435-43a8-b170-bfe38c05a616].
source_passage_text: The engagement of a Recognised Clearing House or Remote Clearing House will be deemed sufficient to satisfy Rule 3.8.1.
target_passage_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange, when engaging a Clearing Service, must ensure that satisfactory arrangements are made for securing the timely discharge (whether by performance, compromise or otherwise), Clearing and settlement of the rights and liabilities of the parties to transactions effected on the Recognised Investment Exchange (being rights and liabilities in relation to those transactions).

question: Under what conditions may the Regulator disclose a statement made by a person to an investigator during an interview conducted pursuant to section 206(1)(a) to a law enforcement agency for criminal proceedings, and how does this relate to the Investigator's authority to require attendance at interviews?
answer: The Regulator is prohibited from disclosing a statement made by a person to an investigator during an interview conducted under section 206(1)(a) to any law enforcement agency for criminal proceedings unless the person consents to the disclosure or the Regulator is required by law or court order to do so [#SRC:7585319d-2470-46fc-975e-d1a88a2805d6]. This confidentiality requirement is linked to the Investigator's authority, which includes the power to require a person to attend an interview at a specified time and place and answer questions [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. Thus, while the Investigator can compel attendance and questioning, the subsequent use of any statements made is tightly controlled to protect the individual's confidentiality unless specific conditions are met.
source_passage_text: In addition to the overriding duty of confidentiality set out in section 198, section 207(2) of the FSMR prohibits the Regulator from disclosing a statement made by a person to an investigator at an interview conducted pursuant to section 206(1)(a) to any law enforcement agency for the purpose of criminal proceedings against that person unless: (a) the person consents to the disclosure; or (b) the Regulator is required by law or court order to disclose the statement.
target_passage_text: The Investigator may, by written notice, require the person who is the Person Under Investigation or any other person (whether or not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to— (a) attend an interview at a Specified time and place and answer questions; (b) produce at a Specified time and place any Specified Documents or Documents of a Specified description; (c) provide such information as the Investigator may require; (d) provide such assistance as the Investigator may require; or (e) permit the Investigator to enter the business premises of such person during normal business hours for the purpose of inspecting and copying Documents on such premises.

question: Under what circumstances does a person commit an offence or contravention by making a statement or concealing facts, and how do the types of agreements or rights involved differ between the FSMR and these Regulations?
answer: A person commits an offence under Section 102(2) of the FSMR if they make a statement or conceal facts with the intention of inducing, or are reckless as to whether it may induce, another person to enter into or refrain from entering into a Relevant Agreement, or to exercise or refrain from exercising rights conferred by a Designated Investment [#SRC:ccc1bc69-f5cb-4668-a23b-63b9c972177a]. In contrast, under these Regulations, a contravention occurs under similar conditions but extends to actions involving acquiring, disposing of, subscribing for, or underwriting a Financial Instrument, Specified Investment, Accepted Virtual Asset, or Accepted Spot Commodity [#TGT:bd2fec86-0605-4dc6-a24c-4e076626ca58]. Both provisions require the intention or recklessness regarding the inducement of another person, but the scope of the agreements and rights involved differs, with the FSMR focusing on Relevant Agreements and Designated Investments, while these Regulations encompass a broader range of financial activities.
source_passage_text: Section 102(2) of the FSMR. Section 102(2) of the FSMR provides that a person ("P"): "...commits an offence if P makes the statement or conceals the facts with the intention of inducing, or is reckless as to whether making it or concealing them may induce, another person (whether or not the person to whom the statement is made)- (a) to enter into or Offer to enter into, or to refrain from entering or Offering to enter into, a Relevant Agreement, or (b) to exercise, or refrain from exercising, any rights conferred by a Designated Investment."
target_passage_text: P commits a contravention of these Regulations if P makes the statement or conceals the facts with the intention of inducing, or is reckless as to whether making it or concealing them may induce, another person (whether or not the person to whom the statement is made) — (a) to enter into or offer to enter into, or to refrain from entering or offering to enter into; or (b) to acquire, dispose of, subscribe for or underwrite, or refrain from acquiring, disposing of, subscribing for or underwriting; or (c) to exercise, or refrain from exercising, any rights conferred by – a Financial Instrument, a Specified Investment, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity, as applicable.

question: What should a Recognised Investment Exchange do to make sure its rules are clear when letting Financial Instruments trade, and how can it ensure trading is fair and orderly?
answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange should make sure its rules are clear by checking if enough people are interested in the Financial Instrument to create good supply and demand, looking at any limits on who can hold or trade the instrument, and having ways to get information for deciding on trading suspensions [#SRC:d6502039-ce83-47db-bb83-74059097d005]. It also needs to have rules that are easy to understand and follow, ensuring fair and orderly trading, and setting clear criteria for how orders are executed efficiently [#TGT:ba1bf9ad-287d-4116-94cc-6433c0dab99a].
source_passage_text: When determining, for the purposes of Rule 3.3.1, whether it has clear and transparent Business Rules concerning the admission of Financial Instruments to trading on any Multilateral Trading Facility operated by it, a Recognised Investment Exchange should have regard to: (a) whether there is a sufficient range of Persons already holding the Financial Instrument (or, where relevant, the underlying asset) or interested in dealing in it to bring about adequate forces of supply and demand; (b) the extent to which there are any limitations on the Persons who may hold or deal in the Financial Instrument, or the amounts of the Financial Instrument which may be held; and (c) whether it has adequate procedures for obtaining information relevant for determining whether or not to suspend or discontinue trading in that Financial Instrument.
target_passage_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange must ensure that it has transparent and non-discretionary Business Rules and procedures to provide for fair and orderly trading, and to establish objective criteria for the efficient execution of orders.

question: What details must a Petroleum Reporting Entity include when sharing new, important estimates of Prospective Resources, and how does this connect to updates on past information?
answer: When a Petroleum Reporting Entity shares new, important estimates of Prospective Resources, it must include details about the types of permits or licenses held for these estimates [#TGT:f8ce6673-be91-48c3-9403-6a5f5e63cc55]. The entity should also describe how they estimated these resources, what further Exploration activities are planned, and when these activities are expected to occur [#TGT:f8ce6673-be91-48c3-9403-6a5f5e63cc55]. Additionally, the entity must assess the chances of discovering and developing these resources and explain any risk factors involved [#TGT:f8ce6673-be91-48c3-9403-6a5f5e63cc55]. This information must be linked to any updates or changes to previously disclosed information about Prospective Resources under specific rules [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704].
source_passage_text: A Petroleum Reporting Entity making a disclosure under Rule 12.6.1 must ensure the disclosure contains: (1) the types of permits or licences held by the Petroleum Reporting Entity relating to the estimates; (2) an explanation of the new data and information; (3) an explanation of how the new data and information has affected the estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Resources; and (4) any changes or additions to the information previously disclosed relating to: (a) Prospective Resources under Rules 12.8.1(1) to 12.8.1(4); (b) Contingent Resources under Rules 12.10.1(1) to 12.10.1(5); and (c) Petroleum Reserves under Rules 12.12.1(1) to 12.12.1(7).
target_passage_text: A Petroleum Reporting Entity disclosing estimates of Prospective Resources that are material and that have not previously been disclosed by the Petroleum Reporting Entity, must ensure the disclosure contains: (1) the types of permits or licenses held by the Petroleum Reporting Entity for the disclosed estimates of Prospective Resources; (2) a description of: (a) the method of estimation; (b) any further Exploration activities to be undertaken (including studies, further data acquisition and evaluation work, and Exploration drilling); and (c) the expected timing of those Exploration activities; (3) the Petroleum Reporting Entity’s assessment of the likelihood of discovery and development associated with the disclosed estimates of Prospective Resources; and (4) an explanation of the relevant risk factors.

question: Under what circumstances is an Insider prohibited from disclosing Inside Information according to Section 92(3), and how does this align with the general prohibition on such disclosures?
answer: An Insider is prohibited from disclosing Inside Information to another person unless it is in the proper course of their employment, profession, or duties [#SRC:8f77978a-8215-43c3-a41b-20e6843ea3a6]. This aligns with the general prohibition on such disclosures, which also restricts the sharing of Inside Information outside the proper course of professional activities [#TGT:24c9495c-026d-446e-865a-9051fa94f13b].
source_passage_text: Section 92(3) prohibits conduct where an Insider discloses Inside Information to another person otherwise than in the proper course of the exercise of his employment, profession or duties.
target_passage_text: The second is where an Insider discloses Inside Information to another person otherwise than in the proper course of the exercise of his employment, profession or duties.

question: How must an Authorised Person calculate E* for CR Exposures to a single Counterparty under a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, considering both the supervisory or own estimate haircuts and potential market fluctuations?
answer: An Authorised Person must calculate E* for all its CR Exposures to any single Counterparty covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement by substituting E* for E when determining the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount under Section 4.8 [#SRC:56e2cb44-f613-4f2a-bd4c-8726a79a5776]. This calculation requires adjusting both the Exposure amount to the Counterparty and the value of any Collateral received to account for potential future market fluctuations, using the methods and haircuts specified in Rules A4.3.6 to A4.3.29 [#TGT:2680d877-e922-4ecb-8fc1-60f4b4c13314].
source_passage_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT that is covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and using the FCCA, must calculate E* for all its CR Exposures to any single Counterparty covered by the qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, in accordance with Rules A4.3.2 to A4.3.6 in App4 (if the Authorised Person is using supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts), and substitute E* for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for its CR Exposures to that Counterparty under Section 4.8.
target_passage_text: Calculation of E* for collateralised transactions other than OTC Derivative transactions and long settlement transactions. An Authorised Person using the FCCA to calculate E* must adjust both the amount of the Exposure to the Counterparty and the value of any Collateral received in support of that Counterparty to take into account possible future fluctuations in the value of either due to market movements, by using the methods and haircuts set out in Rules A4.3.6 to A4.3.29.

question: What procedures must the Regulator follow when it does not give its approval, and how do these procedures relate to the process for making directions or refusing a Recognition Order?
answer: When the Regulator does not give its approval, it must follow the procedure outlined in Rule 6.9.6 [#SRC:fabe80d0-c823-4b53-bd71-de06ee4afccf]. This procedure is related to the process the Regulator follows when exercising its powers to make directions or refuse a Recognition Order, except in certain cases such as revocation with consent or when it is deemed reasonably necessary to deviate from the procedure [#TGT:8f0e941a-957c-499b-952d-fa26d94c0efd]. The Regulator must provide written notice to the Recognised Body or Applicant, stating the reasons for the proposed action and inviting representations within a specified period [#TGT:8f0e941a-957c-499b-952d-fa26d94c0efd]. It must consider any representations made and notify the Recognised Body or Applicant of its decision in writing [#TGT:8f0e941a-957c-499b-952d-fa26d94c0efd].
source_passage_text: The Regulator will follow the procedure set out in Rule 6.9.6 if it does not give its approval.
target_passage_text: The procedures that the Regulator will follow in exercising its powers to make directions or refuse to make a Recognition Order (except in the case of a revocation of a Recognition Order, the Recognised Body concerned has given its consent or, in case where the Regulator proposes to make a direction, it considers it is reasonably necessary not to follow, or to cut short, the procedure) are: /Table Start The Regulator will: Guidance 1. give written notice to the Recognised Body (or Applicant); The notice will state why the Regulator intends to take the action it proposes to take, and include an invitation to make representations, and the period within which representations should be made (unless subsequently extended by the Regulator). 2. receive representations from the Recognised Body or Applicant concerned; The Regulator will not usually consider oral representations without first receiving written representations from the Recognised Body or Applicant. It will normally only hear oral representations from the Recognised Body or Applicant on request. 3. write promptly to the Recognised Body or Applicant who requests the opportunity to make oral representations if it decides not to hear that Person's representations; The Regulator will indicate why it will not hear oral representations and the Regulator will allow the Recognised Body or Applicant further time to respond. 4. have regard to representations made; 5. (when it has reached its decision) notify the Recognised Body or Applicant concerned in writing. /Table End
