question: What must an Authorised Person keep in their Resolution Pack, and how should they manage these documents?
answer: An Authorised Person must keep a Resolution Pack with specific documents, including a master document for retrieval, details of institutions for Client Money and Safe Custody Assets, and information on key managers and agents [#TGT:9a2f70fe-ca63-4b72-a573-f428b37a1a24]. They must also have agreements with these institutions and third parties, and procedures for managing Client Money or Safe Custody Assets [#TGT:9a2f70fe-ca63-4b72-a573-f428b37a1a24]. These documents must be maintained at all times and retrievable as described in the chapter [#SRC:9dc5d839-07b0-4c04-9b95-1b5733012807].
source_passage_text: An Authorised Person falling within Rule 16.1 must maintain at all times and be able to retrieve, in the manner described in this chapter, the documents and records specified in Rule 16.3.1 and Rule 16.4.1 (the "Resolution Pack").
target_passage_text: An Authorised Person must include within its Resolution Pack: (a) a master document containing information sufficient to retrieve each document in the Authorised Person's Resolution Pack; (b) a document which identifies the institutions the Authorised Person has appointed: (i) in the case of Client Money or Relevant money, to hold and maintain Client Accounts or Payment accounts, respectively; and (ii) in the case of Safe Custody Assets, for the deposit of those assets in accordance with Rule ‎15.5.1; (c) a document which identifies each tied agent, field representative or other agent of the Authorised Person which receives Client Money or Safe Custody Assets in its capacity as the Authorised Person's agent in accordance with Rule ‎15.5.1 and Rule ‎15.6; (d) a document which identifies all senior manager, directors and other individuals, and the nature of their responsibility within the Authorised Person or elsewhere, that are critical or important to the performance of operational functions related to any of the obligations imposed on the Authorised Person by this chapter; (e) for each institution identified in Rule 16.3.1 (b) a copy of each executed agreement, including any side letters or other agreements used to clarify or modify the terms of the executed agreement, between that institution and the Authorised Person that relates to the holding of Client Money, Relevant Money or Safe Custody Assets; (f) a document which: (i) identifies each member of the Authorised Person's Group involved in operational functions related to any obligations imposed on the Authorised Person under this chapter, including, in the case of a member that is a nominee company, identification as such; and (ii) identifies each third party which the Authorised Person uses for the performance of operational functions related to any of the obligations imposed on the Authorised Person by this chapter; (g) for each Group member identified in Rule 16.3.1(b), the type of entity (such as branch, subsidiary and/or nominee company) the Group member is, its jurisdiction of incorporation if applicable, and a description of its related operational functions; (h) a copy of each executed agreement, including any side letters or other agreements used to clarify or modify the terms of the executed agreement, between the Authorised Person and each third party identified in Rule 16.3.1(b); (i) where the Authorised Person relies on a third party identified in Rule 16.3.1(c), a document which describes how to: (i) gain access to relevant information held by that third party; and (ii) effect a transfer of any of the Client Money, Relevant Money or Safe Custody Assets held by the Authorised Person, but controlled by that third party; and (j) a copy of the Authorised Person's manual which records its procedures for the management, recording and transfer of the Client Money, Relevant Money or Safe Custody Assets that it holds.

question: What are the obligations of an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business regarding the reconciliation of Client Money and Client Investments, and how do these obligations relate to the records required in the Resolution Pack?
answer: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business is required to maintain adequate systems and controls to ensure that accurate reconciliations of Client Accounts are performed at least every calendar month [#TGT:2b1f7591-fc25-4d91-a3bd-88140fd07c1b]. These reconciliations must be documented and included in the Resolution Pack as per Rules 14.11.1 and 15.9.1, which mandate the inclusion of the most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. This ensures that the Authorised Person not only conducts regular reconciliations but also maintains a comprehensive record of these reconciliations for regulatory review.
source_passage_text: The following records must be included in the Resolution Pack of an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business: (a) Rules 2.7.1 and 3.7.1(d) (records of Client classification and Client agreements); (b) Rules 14.6.2 and 15.4.3 (master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client Money and Client investments); (c) Rule 15.4.4 and Rule 15.4.5 (adequate records and Client's written permission re use of Client Investments); (d) Rules 14.7.1 and 14.7.4 (assessment of appropriateness of Third-Party Agent and acknowledgement by Third-Party agent in respect of Client Money); and (e) Rule 15.5.1 and 15.6.1 (assessment of appropriateness of Third Party Agent and acknowledgement by Third-Party Agent in respect of Client Investments); and (f) Rule 14.11.1 and 15.9.1 (most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments).
target_passage_text: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must maintain adequate systems and controls to ensure that accurate reconciliations of Client Accounts are carried out as regularly as necessary but at least every calendar month.

question: In the context of an Issuer making an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, what obligations arise if there is a significant change or new matter affecting the Prospectus after its issuance?
answer: When an Issuer makes an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, they are required to publish a Prospectus under Section 61 of FSMR [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd]. If, after the issuance of this Prospectus, there is a significant change, a material mistake, or inaccuracy, or a significant new matter arises, the Issuer or the person responsible for the Prospectus must issue a supplementary prospectus [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c]. This supplementary prospectus must provide details of the change, mistake, inaccuracy, or new matter and comply with the requirements set out in section 62(1) [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c].
source_passage_text: Regulatory treatment of tokens deemed to be Securities. The requirements for Offers of Securities fall under Sections 58 to 71 of FSMR and Chapter 4 of the Markets Rules (MKT). When an Issuer wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, these requirements include, for example, the obligation to publish a Prospectus under Section 61 of FSMR.
target_passage_text: Prospectus requirement. Obligation to issue a supplementary prospectus If at any time after the issue of a Prospectus there is a significant change in, or a material mistake or inaccuracy affecting any matter contained in the Prospectus or a significant new matter arises, the Issuer or the person responsible for the issue of the Prospectus shall issue a supplementary prospectus which— (a) provides details of the change, mistake, inaccuracy or new matter; and (b) complies with the requirements in section ‎62‎(1).

question: Under what circumstances may the Regulator take action against a Fund Manager or its Agent promoting a Passported Fund in ADGM, and what actions may be taken if the activities are materially prejudicial despite measures by the Home Regulator?
answer: The Regulator may take action against a Fund Manager, its Agent, or any other Licensed Person promoting a Passported Fund in ADGM if their activities continue to be materially prejudicial to the Unitholders situated in ADGM or to the financial stability or integrity of ADGM, despite any measures taken by the Home Regulator [#TGT:722d2090-eec8-4ae1-8d98-db9a10f13e55]. In such cases, the Regulator may prevent further promotion of the Passported Fund, de-register the fund from its Register of Passported Funds, or impose a penalty on the Fund Manager, its Agent, or any other Licensed Person, following consultation with the Home Regulator [#SRC:d4ba7643-bc71-443d-aab5-fac9738f8ae5].
source_passage_text: Subject to Rule 9.5.2, the Regulator may take any action that is necessary and appropriate to enable it to further its objectives, including, but not limited to: (a) preventing the Fund Manager, its Agent or any other Licensed Person from further Promotion of the Passported Fund in ADGM, including de-registering the relevant Passported Fund from its Register of Passported Funds; and (b) imposing a penalty on the Fund Manager, its Agent or any other Licensed Person, of such amount as it considers appropriate under applicable ADGM legislation, following consultation with the Home Regulator.
target_passage_text: If, despite the measures (if any) taken by a Home Regulator in relation to a Passported Fund, a Fund Manager's activities (or the activities of its Agent or any other Licensed Person that is Promoting the Passported Fund) in ADGM continue to be materially prejudicial to either: (a) the Unitholders of the Passported Fund who are situated in ADGM; or (b) the financial stability or the integrity of ADGM, the Regulator may request urgent discussions with the Home Regulator who has the supervision and enforcement responsibilities in respect of the Passported Fund.

question: Under what conditions may a Recognised Investment Exchange operate an MTF or OTF using Accepted Spot Commodities, and what specific framework must it comply with?
answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange (RIE) may operate a Multilateral Trading Facility (MTF) or Organised Trading Facility (OTF) using Accepted Spot Commodities if its Recognition Order includes a stipulation permitting such operations [#SRC:3b0fe405-26d0-4f37-83e9-73ab112be809]. When this stipulation is present, the RIE must adhere to the Spot Commodities Framework specifically for the operation of the MTF or OTF [#SRC:3b0fe405-26d0-4f37-83e9-73ab112be809]. Additionally, the specific rules on MTFs and OTFs outlined in COBS will apply to the function of operating the MTF or OTF, but only to that function [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388].
source_passage_text: REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS - SPOT COMMODITY ACTIVITIES RIEs operating an MTF or OTF using Accepted Spot Commodities Pursuant to MIR Rule 3.4.1, an RIE may operate an MTF or OTF, provided that its Recognition Order includes a stipulation permitting it to do so. MIR Rule 3.4.2 requires that where such a stipulation is granted to an RIE, the RIE must meet the requirements of the Spot Commodities Framework in relation to operation of the MTF or OTF (using Spot Commodities) while the remainder of its operations must be operated in compliance with the MIR Rules.
target_passage_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange may carry on the Regulated Activity of operating an MTF or OTF provided that its Recognition Order includes a stipulation permitting it to do so. If it does include such a stipulation, the specific rules on MTFs and OTFs in COBS will apply to that function, but that function only.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a subsequent disclosure referring to previously disclosed Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, what are the requirements regarding the Competent Person and the original disclosure?
answer: In a subsequent disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity that refers to previously disclosed Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, the entity must reference the earlier disclosure that complied with Rule 11.12.1 [#SRC:9819bc20-c088-4225-b398-fd241c8b322d]. Additionally, the entity must confirm that no new information or data materially affects the earlier disclosed information and that all material assumptions and technical parameters remain unchanged [#SRC:9819bc20-c088-4225-b398-fd241c8b322d]. Furthermore, the disclosure must state that it is based on information prepared by a named Competent Person, including whether the Competent Person is an employee or a Related Party, and the name of their employer if applicable [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203].
source_passage_text: Competent Persons . Rule 11.12.1 only applies the first time a Mining Reporting Entity discloses Exploration Results in accordance with Rule 11.4 or original or updated estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with Rules 11.5 or 11.6 provided that: (1) any subsequent disclosure that refers to those Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with Rule 11.12.1; and (2) the Mining Reporting Entity confirms in the subsequent disclosure that it is not aware of any new information or data that materially affects the information included in the earlier disclosure(s) and, in the case of estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, that all material assumptions and technical parameters underpinning the estimates in the earlier disclosure(s) continue to apply and have not materially changed.
target_passage_text: Competent Persons . Subject to Rule 11.12.2, a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity containing Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves must state: (1) that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s); (2) in each case, whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party and, if not, the name of the Competent Person’s employer; and (3) in each case, the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member.

question: If an Authorised Person runs a Multilateral Trading Facility for Virtual Assets, what rules do they need to follow, including any special chapters or sections?
answer: An Authorised Person running a Multilateral Trading Facility for Virtual Assets must follow several rules. They need to meet the general requirements for any Authorised Person doing Regulated Activities with Virtual Assets, as mentioned in Rules 17.1 to 17.6 [#SRC:24637efb-9ce5-40ee-bec4-7e5066d40d24]. They also have to comply with specific sections in COBS, MIR, and GEN, as outlined in Rules 17.7.2 to 17.7.6 [#SRC:24637efb-9ce5-40ee-bec4-7e506d40d24]. If they provide custody for Virtual Assets, Rule 17.8 is also relevant [#SRC:24637efb-9ce5-40ee-bec4-7e506d40d24]. Additionally, they must follow the rules in COBS, Chapter 8, which specifically apply to those operating a Multilateral Trading Facility for Virtual Assets [#TGT:7cf37a88-ab41-4ec4-a018-7d040a752c1f].
source_passage_text: In addition to the general requirements applicable to an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets as set out in Rules 17.1 17.6, an Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets must comply with the requirements set out in: (a) COBS, MIR and GEN, as set out in Rules 17.7.2 17.7.6; and (b) Rule 17.8 if also Providing Custody in relation to Virtual Assets.
target_passage_text: An Authorised Person that is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets must comply with the requirements set out in COBS, Chapter 8.

question: Under what conditions must a Mining Reporting Entity disclose a material difference in its Production results, and how does this relate to the concept of Inside Information for Financial Instruments?
answer: A Mining Reporting Entity must disclose a material difference in its Production results if it becomes aware that these results will significantly deviate from any previously disclosed Production Target. This obligation arises under Rule 7.2.1 and section 95(2) of FSMR, as such information, if generally available, would likely have a significant effect on the price of Financial Instruments [#SRC:09aca426-0526-4305-9aa4-12e87c9b3c96]. This aligns with the concept of Inside Information, which is defined as information of a precise nature that is not generally available and would likely impact the price of Financial Instruments if it were available. Inside Information must relate directly or indirectly to the Reporting Entities or Issuers of the Financial Instruments [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977].
source_passage_text: Production Targets-Disclosure requirements . If a Mining Reporting Entity becomes aware that its Production results will differ materially (up or down) from any Production Target it has disclosed, it may have a legal obligation to disclose this. This obligation to disclose may arise under Rule 7.2.1 and section 95(2) of FSMR, in order to disclose information that would, if generally available, be likely to have a significant effect on the price... of Financial Instruments.
target_passage_text: In relation to Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities or Related Instruments which are not Commodity Derivatives, Inside Information is information of a Precise nature which— (a) is not generally available; (b) relates, directly or indirectly, to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers of the Financial Instruments or to one or more of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; and (c) would, if generally available, be likely to have a significant effect on the price of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities or Related Instruments.

question: When does a Payment Service Provider not have to give the usual payment details after starting a Payment Order if it's done through a Payment Instrument under a Framework Contract?
answer: A Payment Service Provider does not have to give the usual payment details after starting a Payment Order if the order is made through a Payment Instrument under a Framework Contract. This is because the general information required by Rule 19.5.1 may already be provided or will be provided by another Payment Service Provider under Section 19.2 for the Framework Contract [#TGT:c337e2ea-0d58-45b9-970f-810639f88bf2]. Normally, these details include confirmation of the order, transaction reference, amount, charges, exchange rate, and the Credit Value Date [#SRC:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622].
source_passage_text: Subject to Rule 19.5.3, a Payment Service Provider must provide or make available to the Payer and, where applicable, to the Payee, immediately after the initiation of a Payment Order: (a) confirmation of the successful initiation of the Payment Order with the Payers Payment Service Provider; (b) a reference enabling the Payer and the Payee to identify the Payment Transaction, including the Payer and Payee, and, where appropriate, any information transferred with the Payment Order; (c) the amount of the Payment Transaction, in the currency used in the Payment Order; (d) the amount of any charges payable in relation to the Payment Transaction and, where applicable, a breakdown of the amounts of such charges expressed in the currency of the Payment Order; (e) where an exchange rate is used in the Payment Transaction the actual rate used or a reference to it, and the amount of the Payment Transaction after that currency conversion; (f) the date on which the Payment Service Provider received the Payment Order; and (g) the Credit Value Date.
target_passage_text: Where a Payment Order for an individual Payment Transaction is transmitted by way of a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract, the Payment Service Provider in respect of that single Payment Transaction need not provide or make available under Rule 19.5.1 the general information which has been provided or will be provided under Section 19.2 by another Payment Service Provider in respect of a Framework Contract.

question: What must be true for an Authorised Person to recognise a guarantee from an MDB for credit risk mitigation, and what is the risk weight for these MDBs?
answer: For an Authorised Person to recognise a guarantee from an MDB for credit risk mitigation, the MDB must be one referred to in Rule 4.12.8 [#SRC:281505d3-a15a-449a-9095-dc247d0e2e5d]. The risk weight for exposures to these MDBs is 0% [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4]. This includes entities like the World Bank Group and the Asian Development Bank [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4].
source_passage_text: An Authorised Person may recognise the effects of CRM of a guarantee only if it is provided by any of the following entities: (a) central government or central bank; (b) MDB referred to in Rule 4.12.8; (c) International Organisations referred to in Rule 4.12.9; (d) PSE; (e) banks and Securities firms which qualify for inclusion in bank asset class; or (f) any other entity that has an external credit assessment from a recognised credit rating agency that maps to a Credit Quality Grade 3 or better.
target_passage_text: Multilateral development bank (MDB) asset class. An Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight to any CR Exposure to the qualifying MDBs set out below: (a) The World Bank Group comprised of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA), and the International Finance Corporation (IFC); (b) The Asian Development Bank (ADB); (c) The African Development Bank (AfDB); (d) The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD); (e) The Inter American Development Bank (IADB); (f) The European Investment Bank (EIB); (g) The European Investment Fund (EIF); (h) The Nordic Investment Bank (NIB); (i) The Caribbean Development Bank (CDB); (j) The Islamic Development Bank (IDB); and (k) The Council of Europe Development Bank (CEDB).

question: If an MTF wants to list Exempt Offer Securities, what must it do about the number of Retail Clients and the systems it uses?
answer: When an MTF wants to list Exempt Offer Securities, it must follow certain rules to ensure proper trading. The MTF can allow these Securities to be traded by an unlimited number of Professional Clients and up to 200 Retail Clients, as long as these Retail Clients have been assessed to have the right knowledge and experience about the risks involved [#SRC:1afc74c9-338e-44c8-8b6b-bba509c5946f]. The MTF must also have systems and controls to ensure only Securities from Exempt Offers made on its platform are admitted, identify who the Exempt Offer was made to, and limit trading to no more than 200 people who are not Professional Clients [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66]. It must also comply with specific trading admission rules and provide users with access to important information about the Securities [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66].
source_passage_text: In respect of Securities offered by Exempt Offer, whether previously offered through a PFP or not, an MTF Operator may list Exempt Offer Securities on the MTF, enabling such Securities to be traded amongst an unlimited number of Professional Clients and not more than 200 Retail Clients which have been assessed by the MTF Operator to possess appropriate knowledge and experience of the relevant risks, in accordance with Market Infrastructure Rules (MIR) Rule 2.8.3. A description of the systems and controls required to be employed by a MTF Operator that seeks to admit Exempt Offer Securities to trading is set out in Conduct of Business Rules (COBS) Rule 8.2.2.
target_passage_text: An MTF that admits to trading Securities that are offered by way of an Exempt Offer under MKT Rule 4.3.1 (13) shall ensure that it has effective systems and controls in place to: (a) admit only Securities of such Exempt Offers that are made on its own platform; (b) identify those Persons to whom the Exempt Offer was made; (c) restrict trading of the Securities, to no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients; (d) comply with MIR rule 3.9.1 (Admission to trading), as applicable in relation to the relevant Securities; and (e) allow users of its market to obtain Inside Information, including any Offer documents pursuant to MKT Rule 4.3.5 relevant to the Securities.

question: How does Rule 9.3.4 interact with the HQLA requirement for an Authorised Person, particularly in maintaining liquidity under stress conditions?
answer: Rule 9.3.4 establishes a minimum level requirement, which complements the broader mandate of Rule 9.3.3, ensuring that an Authorised Person maintains adequate liquidity [#SRC:749afea1-d63d-4350-83ca-1bc3e08aa551]. This aligns with the HQLA requirement that mandates an Authorised Person to always maintain sufficient High-Quality Liquid Assets (HQLA) to cover liquidity needs for at least 30 calendar days during a severe stress scenario [#TGT:93fbc822-3e3f-41ed-9356-02a43f97fcdc]. The conditions for assets to qualify as HQLA are detailed in Rules A10.2.2 to A10.2.9 in App10 [#TGT:93fbc822-3e3f-41ed-9356-02a43f97fcdc].
source_passage_text: Rule 9.3.4 sets a minimum level and is not intended to limit the generality of the requirement in Rule 9.3.3.
target_passage_text: HQLA requirement. An Authorised Person must at all times maintain an adequate level of HQLA to meet its liquidity needs for a minimum 30 calendar day period under a severe stress scenario. Rules A10.2.2 to A10.2.9 in App10 set out the conditions for assets to be treated as HQLA.

question: How must an Authorised Person determine the qualifying Capital Resources of a Subsidiary included in the consolidated Capital Resources of its Financial Group, considering the calculation of the Total Risk Exposure Amount?
answer: An Authorised Person must determine the qualifying Capital Resources of a Subsidiary included in the consolidated Capital Resources of its Financial Group by subtracting a specific amount from the Subsidiary's qualifying Capital Resources. This specific amount is calculated by multiplying the lesser of two values by a percentage. The first value is the amount of Capital Resources required to meet the Subsidiary's total Capital Requirement, which is 10.0% of its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated according to Rule 3.5.7, and its Combined Buffer Requirement [#SRC:9828ecf6-13e6-4602-802b-b198835d9d99]. The Total Risk Exposure Amount itself is the sum of several components, including the Credit RWA, Market Risk Capital Requirement, Operational Risk Capital Requirement, CVA Risk Capital Requirement, and Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement, as calculated under various rules [#TGT:25b7dc85-4ef9-4582-864d-fcfc50e1578e].
source_passage_text: Qualifying Capital Resources included in consolidated Capital Resources. An Authorised Person must determine the amount of qualifying Capital Resources of a Subsidiary that is included in consolidated Capital Resources of its Financial Group by subtracting from the qualifying Capital Resources of that Subsidiary, the result of multiplying the amount referred to in (a) by the percentage referred to in (b): (a) the lesser of the following: (i) the amount of Capital Resources of the Subsidiary required to meet the sum of the Subsidiary's total Capital Requirement (on a solo basis) of 10.0% of its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7 and its Combined Buffer Requirement; or (ii) the amount of Capital Resources that relates to the Subsidiary that is required on a consolidated basis to meet the sum of its Financial Group's total Capital Requirement of 10.0% of its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, and its Combined Buffer Requirement; (b) the qualifying Capital Resources of the Subsidiary, expressed as a percentage of all Capital Resources instruments of the Subsidiary that are included in its CET1, AT1 and T2 Capital items and the related retained earnings and Share premium accounts.
target_passage_text: Total Risk Exposure Amount. An Authorised Person must calculate its Total Risk Exposure Amount, after taking into account the provisions of Rule 3.5.8, as the sum of: (a) the Credit RWA as calculated using Rule 4.8.1(2); (b) the Risk Exposure Amount associated with the Market Risk Capital Requirement; (c) the Risk Exposure Amount associated with the Operational Risk Capital Requirement; (d) the Risk Exposure Amount associated with the CVA Risk Capital Requirement; and (e) the Risk Exposure Amount associated with Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement, where applicable, calculated in accordance with IFR Rule 5.4.5.

question: Do the rules in chapter 4 about Prospectuses apply when someone offers Units of Funds?
answer: The rules in chapter 4 about Prospectuses do not apply when someone offers Units of Funds, as these are covered by the Fund Rules instead [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94]. Also, the provisions of the Chapter do not apply to a person making an Offer of a Unit [#TGT:07edf917-eba6-4ad8-8173-a8d5bc0ec58a].
source_passage_text: The Prospectus requirements including content and structure in chapter 4 of this Rulebook do not apply to Prospectuses relating to Units of Funds. Prospectus requirements that apply to an Offer of Units of Funds are found in the Fund Rules. Section 57(1) of FSMR disapplies chapter 4 of this Rulebook to Fund Prospectuses.
target_passage_text: The provisions in this Chapter and the Rules made for the purposes of this Chapter shall not apply to a person in relation to making an Offer of a Unit.

question: How can a Reporting Entity get the Regulator to halt trading, and what is the time limit for this halt?
answer: A Reporting Entity can ask the Regulator to halt trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange to give a Listed Entity time to disclose inside information [#TGT:3c104b3f-3048-4f80-a73d-5afba38f3887]. The halt can last up to two Business Days, but it can be shorter if the Regulator agrees [#SRC:88d53574-f94b-4da4-8a47-2afa2fd511db].
source_passage_text: A Trading Halt imposed pursuant to Rule 7.8.1 cannot exceed two Business Days or such shorter period as the Regulator agrees.
target_passage_text: The Regulator may, at any time and upon the request of a Reporting Entity, halt trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange of Securities of a Listed Entity to enable the Listed Entity time to Disclose Inside information.

question: When can the Regulator tell an Authorised Person to send in returns differently than usual, and what must the Authorised Person do if this happens?
answer: The Regulator can tell an Authorised Person to send in returns differently than usual by giving a written notice [#TGT:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b]. If this happens, the Authorised Person must follow the new instructions until the Regulator changes them again with another written notice [#TGT:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b]. The Authorised Person also needs to prepare its returns according to the Rules in the Chapter, PRU guidelines, and the Electronic Prudential Reporting System (EPRS) requirements, including how often to submit them [#SRC:d384c02a-97aa-458d-9961-3b9b406ec6f9].
source_passage_text: An Authorised Person must, subject to Rule 2.3.3: (a) prepare its returns in accordance with the Rules in this Chapter, the instructional guidelines in PRU and elsewhere, and the requirements of the Electronic Prudential Reporting System (EPRS) of the Regulator including the frequency of submission detailed therein; and (b) submit the returns to the Regulator using EPRS.
target_passage_text: The Regulator may by way of a written notice direct an Authorised Person to submit its returns in a form, manner or frequency other than as prescribed in Rule 2.3.2. An Authorised Person must continue to submit its returns in accordance with this direction until the Regulator by way of written notice directs otherwise.

question: When an Authorised Person applies for a Financial Services Permission to operate a Multilateral Trading Facility involving Virtual Assets, what considerations must the Regulator take into account, and how should references to Investment be interpreted?
answer: When an Authorised Person applies for a Financial Services Permission to operate a Multilateral Trading Facility involving Virtual Assets, the Regulator must consider several factors. These include whether the establishment of the facility is in the interests of the Financial Services and Markets industry, whether it will enhance price discovery or liquidity in an Investment, and whether there is a risk of market fragmentation or inefficiency in price discovery [#TGT:66edbeb0-e20b-498a-8b25-cfd2a59dae31]. Additionally, for an Authorised Person operating such a facility, all references to Investment must be interpreted as references to Virtual Assets [#SRC:726a7101-d094-4454-93b6-5e5561582705].
source_passage_text: GEN Rule 5.2.14 shall apply to an Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, and all references to Investment shall be read as references to Virtual Asset.
target_passage_text: In assessing an application for a Financial Services Permission authorising the applicant to Operate a Multilateral Trading Facility or an Organised Trading Facility, the Regulator will have regard to, but is not limited to, considering the following matters: (1) whether the establishment of a Multilateral Trading Facility or Organised Trading Facility is, or is likely to be, in the interests of the Financial Services and Markets industry; (2) whether the Multilateral Trading Facility or Organised Trading Facility will or is likely to lead to more efficient price discovery of, or deepen liquidity in, an Investment; and (3) whether there is any risk of market fragmentation, loss of liquidity or inefficiency in price discovery as a result of the proposed Multilateral Trading Facility or Organised Trading Facility operation.

question: How should an Authorised Person calculate the Exposure value for Derivatives, including written credit protection, considering both the on-balance sheet requirements and the Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR)?
answer: An Authorised Person must calculate the Exposure value for Derivatives, including written credit protection, by summing the on-balance sheet value in accordance with IFRS and an add-on for potential future Exposure, as specified in Rules A4.6.14 to A4.6.21 of Appendix 4 [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007]. Additionally, under the Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR), the Exposure at Default (EAD) should be calculated separately for each netting set using the formula EAD = alpha * (RC + PFE), where alpha equals 1.4, RC is the replacement cost calculated according to Rules A4.6.19 to A4.6.24, and PFE is the potential future exposure calculated according to Rule A4.6.26 [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918]. This dual approach ensures comprehensive coverage of both current and potential future exposures.
source_passage_text: In relation to on-balance sheet items: a. for SFTs, the Exposure value should be calculated in accordance with IFRS and the Netting requirements referred to in Rule 4.9.14; b. for Derivatives, including written credit protection, the Exposure value should be calculated as the sum of the on-balance sheet value in accordance with IFRS and an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated in accordance with Rules A4.6.14 to A4.6.21 of App 4; and c. for other on-balance sheet items, the Exposure value should be calculated based on their balance sheet values in accordance with Rule 4.9.3.
target_passage_text: Derivatives and long settlement transactions – Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR). EAD is to be calculated separately for each netting set. It is determined as follows: EAD = alpha* (RC + PFE) where: alpha = 1.4 RC = the replacement cost calculated according to Rules A4.6.19 to A4.6.24 PFE = the amount for potential future exposure calculated according to Rule A4.6.26

question: When can the Regulator share Confidential Information from another authority, and what permissions are needed?
answer: The Regulator can share Confidential Information from another authority only if certain permissions are obtained. The disclosure must align with section 199(2) and related paragraphs, and it is subject to additional conditions [#SRC:09405ca4-fb5d-43b3-bba2-7f2da491d209]. The authority that provided the information must give written consent before the Regulator can disclose it [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c]. If the information is CRD Information, the EEA Competent Authority's consent is also required, and the disclosure must be for the specific purpose for which consent was granted [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c].
source_passage_text: Where the Confidential Information (in whole or in part) originates in another governmental or regulatory authority, the Regulator may only disclose that Confidential Information in accordance with section 199(2), as set out in paragraphs 3.3.3 3.3.4 above, subject to paragraph 3.3.5.
target_passage_text: Paragraphs (1)(b)(i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (vi) and 1(c) do not permit the Regulator to disclose Confidential Information unless the conditions in paragraphs (a) and (b) are met – (a) where the Confidential Information (in whole or in part) originates in another governmental or regulatory authority, whether in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or otherwise, the authority that has disclosed the Confidential Information to the Regulator has given its prior written consent to the disclosure; and (b) where the Confidential Information is CRD Information – (i) EEA Competent Authority that has disclosed the Confidential Information to the Regulator has given its prior written consent to the disclosure; and (ii) if such consent was given for a particular purpose, the disclosure by the Regulator is solely for that purpose.

question: Under what conditions does a Person prescribed by section 70(1) of the FSMR avoid civil liability for losses due to false or misleading statements in a Prospectus, and how does this relate to the liability for compensation as outlined in the Rules made by the Regulator?
answer: A Person prescribed by section 70(1) of the FSMR avoids civil liability for losses arising from false, misleading, or deceptive statements or omissions in a Prospectus if any of the circumstances specified in subsections (2) to (6) apply [#SRC:4bab6b81-d4ed-4745-b082-99a3161debe0]. However, the Rules made by the Regulator stipulate that any person prescribed as liable for a Prospectus must compensate another person who has acquired Securities related to the Prospectus and suffered loss or damage due to any untrue or misleading statement or omission of material matters required by these Regulations [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac]. Thus, while certain conditions may exempt a Person from civil liability under the FSMR, the obligation to compensate under the Regulator's Rules remains unless those specific conditions are met.
source_passage_text: Pursuant to section 70(1) of the FSMR, a Person is hereby prescribed as not incurring civil liability for any loss arising from any false, misleading, or deceptive statement or omission in a Prospectus if any of the circumstances specified in (2) to (6) apply.
target_passage_text: Any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to another person who has acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and who has suffered loss or damage arising from any untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or the omission from it of any material matter required to have been included in the Prospectus by or under these Regulations.

question: Under what conditions may an Authorised Person provide credit to a Related Person on terms more favourable than those available to non-Related Persons, and what procedural requirements must be met according to the Credit Risk policy?
answer: An Authorised Person may provide credit to a Related Person on terms more favourable than those available to non-Related Persons if the credit is extended under an Employee credit policy that is widely available to Employees of the Authorised Person [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91]. This policy must be approved by the Authorised Person's Governing Body or its delegate and must clearly outline the terms, conditions, and limits for providing such credit [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91]. Additionally, the policy must include adequate mechanisms to ensure ongoing compliance, including immediate reporting to the Governing Body or its delegate in case of any deviations or breaches [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91]. Furthermore, if Exposures to Related Persons are allowed on terms no more favourable than those available to non-Related Persons, the policy must require prior written approval from the firm's Governing Body or its delegate for Exposures exceeding specific amounts or posing special risks [#SRC:00064b4f-3f4c-467b-8568-29e635e11496].
source_passage_text: Credit Risk policy. In relation to conflicts of interest and Related Person transactions, the policy must: (a) set out adequate procedures for handling conflicts of interest relating to the provision and management of credit, including measures to prevent any Person directly or indirectly benefiting from the credit being part of the process of granting or managing the credit; (b) subject to Rule 4.4.5, prohibit Exposures to Related Persons on terms that are more favourable than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons; and (c) if Exposures to Related Persons are allowed on terms which are no more favourable than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons, set out procedures that: (i) require such Exposures, and any write off of such Exposures, exceeding specific amounts or otherwise posing special risks to the Authorised Person, to be made subject to the prior written approval of the firm's Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate; and (ii) exclude Persons directly or indirectly benefiting from the grant or write off of such Exposures being part of the approval process.
target_passage_text: Credit Risk policy. The prohibition in Rule 4.4.4(b) does not apply to Providing Credit to a Related Person under a credit policy on terms (such as for credit assessment, tenor, interest rates, amortisation schedules and requirements for Collateral) that are more favourable than those on which it provides credit to Persons who are not Related Persons, provided the credit policy: (a) is an Employee credit policy that is widely available to Employees of the Authorised Person; (b) is approved by the Authorised Person's Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate; (c) clearly sets out the terms, conditions and limits (both at individual and aggregate levels) on which credit is to be provided to such Employees; and (d) requires adequate mechanisms to ensure on going compliance with the terms and conditions of that credit policy, including immediate reporting to the Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate where there is a deviation from or a breach of the terms and conditions or procedures applicable to the provision of such credit for timely and appropriate action.

question: Under what conditions may the Regulator or its agents disclose Confidential Information, considering the requirements for prior consent from both the person from whom the information was obtained and the person to whom it relates?
answer: The Regulator or its agents may disclose Confidential Information only if they have obtained prior consent from both the person from whom the information was originally obtained and, if different, the person to whom the duty of confidentiality is owed. This requirement aligns with the prohibition under section 198(1) of FSMR, which mandates that disclosure is contingent upon obtaining consent from these parties [#SRC:fbbdae87-6f42-49d9-81a9-e75a30466d8a]. Similarly, the TARGET text specifies that a primary recipient or any person obtaining the information from a primary recipient must also secure prior consent from both the person from whom the information was obtained and the person to whom it relates before disclosure [#TGT:db8084a6-8fbb-4197-9e29-8bd14a43f866].
source_passage_text: With prior consent under section 198(1) of FSMR. Section 198(1) prohibits disclosure of Confidential Information by the Regulator, its employees, agents or by any person coming into possession of Confidential Information unless they have the prior consent of (a) the person from whom the Confidential Information was obtained; and, (b) if different, the person to whom the duty of confidentiality is owed (paragraphs 198(1)(a) and (b)).
target_passage_text: Confidential Information must not be disclosed by a primary recipient, or by any person obtaining the information directly or indirectly from a primary recipient, without the prior consent of— (a) the person from whom the primary recipient obtained the information; and (b) if different, the person to whom it relates.

question: Under what circumstances does an Insider engage in Insider Dealing according to Section 92(2) of the FSMR, and how does this relate to the first type of Behaviour described in the regulatory framework?
answer: An Insider engages in Insider Dealing when they deal, or attempt to deal, in a Financial Instrument, Related Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset, or an Accepted Spot Commodity based on Inside Information related to those specific assets [#SRC:030e6555-062f-4aee-a31c-6b6041bdc139]. This aligns with the first type of Behaviour outlined in the regulatory framework, which specifies that such dealing or attempted dealing must occur on the basis of Inside Information concerning the relevant Financial Instruments, Related Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, or Accepted Spot Commodities [#TGT:da3ba0b9-ff62-4830-a771-93c35b02af25].
source_passage_text: Section 92(2) of the FSMR provides that Insider Dealing occurs when: "...an Insider deals, or attempts to deal, in a Financial Instrument, Related Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity on the basis of Inside Information relating to the Financial Instruments, Related Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities in question."
target_passage_text: The first type of Behaviour is where an Insider deals, or attempts to deal, in a Financial Instrument, Related Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity on the basis of Inside Information relating to the Financial Instruments, Related Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities in question.

question: What are the obligations of an MTF Operator when listing Exempt Offer Securities on its platform, particularly in relation to the number of Retail Clients and the systems and controls required?
answer: An MTF Operator that lists Exempt Offer Securities on its platform must adhere to specific obligations to ensure compliance with regulatory requirements. The MTF Operator may enable trading of these Securities among an unlimited number of Professional Clients and up to 200 Retail Clients, provided these Retail Clients have been assessed to possess appropriate knowledge and experience of the relevant risks [#SRC:1afc74c9-338e-44c8-8b6b-bba509c5946f]. Additionally, the MTF must have effective systems and controls to admit only Securities of Exempt Offers made on its platform, identify the Persons to whom the Exempt Offer was made, and restrict trading to no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66]. The MTF must also comply with MIR rule 3.9.1 regarding admission to trading and ensure that users can access Inside Information, including Offer documents relevant to the Securities [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66].
source_passage_text: In respect of Securities offered by Exempt Offer, whether previously offered through a PFP or not, an MTF Operator may list Exempt Offer Securities on the MTF, enabling such Securities to be traded amongst an unlimited number of Professional Clients and not more than 200 Retail Clients which have been assessed by the MTF Operator to possess appropriate knowledge and experience of the relevant risks, in accordance with Market Infrastructure Rules (MIR) Rule 2.8.3. A description of the systems and controls required to be employed by a MTF Operator that seeks to admit Exempt Offer Securities to trading is set out in Conduct of Business Rules (COBS) Rule 8.2.2.
target_passage_text: An MTF that admits to trading Securities that are offered by way of an Exempt Offer under MKT Rule 4.3.1 (13) shall ensure that it has effective systems and controls in place to: (a) admit only Securities of such Exempt Offers that are made on its own platform; (b) identify those Persons to whom the Exempt Offer was made; (c) restrict trading of the Securities, to no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients; (d) comply with MIR rule 3.9.1 (Admission to trading), as applicable in relation to the relevant Securities; and (e) allow users of its market to obtain Inside Information, including any Offer documents pursuant to MKT Rule 4.3.5 relevant to the Securities.

question: When can the FSRA charge extra fees, and how does this compare to when the Regulator can ask for more money?
answer: The FSRA can charge extra fees if it faces a significant extra regulatory burden [#SRC:e19748d8-8b30-466c-8e35-b5a0fd901e72]. Similarly, the Regulator can ask for more money if it expects to spend a lot more time or money on applications, authorisations, filings, or ongoing supervision [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080]. Both situations allow the regulatory bodies to cover the costs of additional work.

question: What must an Authorised Person do each year about the Safe Custody Auditor's Report, and what should be included in this report?
answer: An Authorised Person must submit a Safe Custody Auditor's Report to the Regulator every year if they are allowed to hold Client Investments [#SRC:005cd89b-9c47-4377-a477-1b159acd9ba8]. The report must include details from the Auditor about how much the Authorised Person was involved in holding and controlling Client Investments, Arranging Custody, or Providing Custody at the time their financial statement was prepared [#TGT:99e42871-85c3-4bd8-8cea-8366dc6a7607]. It should also confirm if the Authorised Person kept proper systems and controls to follow the Safe Custody Rules in COBS Chapter 15 all year, if the investments are correctly registered or held, and if there were any big differences in the investment records [#TGT:99e42871-85c3-4bd8-8cea-8366dc6a7607]. The Auditor needs to say if they got all the information needed for the report and if any Safe Custody Provisions were not met [#TGT:99e42871-85c3-4bd8-8cea-8366dc6a7607].
source_passage_text: In accordance with GEN 6.6.7, an Authorised Person whose Financial Service Permission entitles them to hold Client Investments must arrange for a Safe Custody Auditor's Report to be submitted to the Regulator on an annual basis.
target_passage_text: Safe Custody Auditor's Report: An Authorised Person must, in procuring the production of a Safe Custody Auditor's Report by its Auditor, ensure that the Auditor states, as at the date on which the Authorised Person's audited statement of financial position was prepared: (1) the extent to which the Authorised Person was holding and controlling Client Investments, Arranging Custody or Providing Custody; and (2) whether: (a) the Authorised Person has, throughout the year, maintained systems and controls to enable it to comply with the Safe Custody Rules in COBS Chapter 15; (b) the Safe Custody Investments are registered, recorded or held in accordance with the Safe Custody Rules; (c) there have been any material discrepancies in the reconciliation of Safe Custody Investments; (d) the Auditor has received all necessary information and explanations for the purposes of preparing this report to the Regulator; and (e) any of the requirements of the Safe Custody Provisions have not been met.

question: What capital must an Authorised Person hold when dealing with Virtual Assets, and how should this capital be kept?
answer: An Authorised Person dealing with Virtual Assets must hold regulatory capital similar to a Recognised Investment Exchange, which includes an amount equal to six months' operational expenses and possibly an extra buffer of up to six months' expenses, unless the Regulator decides otherwise [#TGT:1f2f00c6-1680-4516-adc8-b360f33ebe96]. This capital must be held in fiat currency due to the specific risks associated with Virtual Assets [#SRC:9795daec-7cae-4276-a676-296830fc723d].
source_passage_text: REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS FOR AUTHORISED PERSONS ENGAGED IN REGULATED ACTIVITIES IN RELATION TO VIRTUAL ASSETS Capital Requirements Given the nature of, and the risks associated with Virtual Assets, COBS Rule 17.3 requires an Authorised Person to hold regulatory capital in a manner consistent with MIR Rule 3.2.1 (being the requirements that a Recognised Investment Exchange must meet). Pursuant to these Rules, regulatory capital held by an Authorised Person must be in fiat form.
target_passage_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange shall hold the following capital: (a) an amount equal to 6 months' operational expenses; plus (b) unless the Regulator directs otherwise, an additional buffer amount of up to a further 6 months' operational expenses.

question: When can the Regulator publish a notice, and what happens if someone appeals the decision?
answer: The Regulator can choose to publish a decision notice, final notice, or any other notice about its powers, except for warning notices [#TGT:de87bb07-107e-4bc3-a834-8f7457702841]. If someone appeals the decision to the Appeals Panel, the Regulator will publish the decision information, including the notice itself [#SRC:9ddabd85-89c9-44a4-a291-0388531f1314].
source_passage_text: Under section 252(3) of FSMR, we have the discretion to publish a decision notice, final notice or any other notice in relation to the exercise of our powers (other than a warning notice), and details about the matter to which the notice relates. Therefore, if a person exercises their right to refer a decision to the Appeals Panel, we will publish appropriate information about that decision, including the notice itself.
target_passage_text: A decision notice, final notice or any other notice in relation to the exercise of the Regulator's powers (other than a warning notice), and details about the matter to which such notice relates, may be published by the Regulator at its discretion.

question: What are the financial and potential regulatory consequences for an Authorised Person who submits a Regulatory Filing after the due date?
answer: An Authorised Person who submits a Regulatory Filing after the due date is required to pay a late payment fee of $500 to the Regulator [#TGT:44e2c477-1fbd-46c4-9391-046045a5b105]. In addition to this financial penalty, the Regulator may impose further actions as outlined in FEES 1.2.7 [#SRC:641ef80a-a631-455c-b981-eb38f3805187].

target_passage_text: Late Payment Fees relating to Regulatory Filings An Authorised Person, a Designated Non-Financial Business or Profession or a Recognised Body that submits a Regulatory Filing after the due date must pay to the Regulator a fee of $500.

question: Under what conditions must an Issuer ensure that its Securities are admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, and how does the requirement for an Approved Prospectus apply in this context?
answer: An Issuer must ensure that its Securities are admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange (RIE) only if those Securities are included in the Official List and are not suspended from it [#SRC:1708447a-ed53-4ba2-977e-dab2f28f5481]. Additionally, the Issuer must have an Approved Prospectus for the relevant Securities, as mandated by section 61(1) of FSMR, which is linked to section 50(3) [#SRC:1708447a-ed53-4ba2-977e-dab2f28f5481]. This requirement is further reinforced by the stipulation that no person shall have Securities admitted to trading on a RIE without an Approved Prospectus in relation to those Securities [#TGT:82ade9b4-bba4-449c-815c-32d6ef292b54].
source_passage_text: DIGITAL SECURITIES & TRADING VENUES Recognised Investment Exchanges (RIEs) Pursuant to section 50(3) of FSMR, a RIE shall not permit trading of Securities on its facilities unless those Securities are admitted to, and not suspended from, the Official List. Section 61(1) of FSMR is linked to section 50(3), such that an Issuer cannot have Securities admitted to trading on a RIE, unless there is an Approved Prospectus in relation to the relevant Securities. An Issuer therefore wanting to have its Securities traded on a RIE needs to have such Securities: a) admitted to the Official List of Securities (maintained by FSRA); and b) offered by way of an Approved Prospectus.
target_passage_text: A person shall not, subject to subsection ‎(3)— (a) make an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market; or (b) have Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange; unless there is an Approved Prospectus in relation to the relevant Securities.

question: What must a PFP Operator do when there are important changes to the information on a Private Financing Platform, and how should they inform PFP Clients?
answer: A PFP Operator must update the information on a Private Financing Platform to reflect important changes, such as risk details, operation terms, and conflict of interest information [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f]. They must also inform PFP Clients about these changes within a reasonable time after they happen [#SRC:40149b11-dcb8-48a6-ab09-8d8c37923183]. This helps ensure that clients are aware of any significant updates that might impact their involvement with the platform.
source_passage_text: A PFP Operator must ensure that the information published in accordance with Rule 18.5.1 is updated to reflect material changes and notice of such material change is provided to PFP Clients within a reasonable timeframe following such change.
target_passage_text: A PFP Operator must ensure that the following information, available to PFP Clients, is published on a Private Financing Platform it operates: (a) a statement identifying the risks involved in participating in financing proposals identified on the Private Financing Platform; (b) a statement confirming that the PFP Operator is not providing credit or investment advice to any PFP Client or PFP Prospect, and advising PFP Clients to seek independent advice prior to entering into any transaction; (c) the terms of operation of the Private Financing Platform, including the PFP Operator’s remuneration model; (d) the details of any potential conflicts of interest between the PFP Operator, PFP Clients and any PFP Prospect; (e) the details of the Eligible Custodian engaged by the PFP Operator, if so appointed; (f) the wind-down arrangements the PFP Operator has in place to ensure the orderly administration of transactions facilitated on the Private Financing Platform it operates in the event of its failure; (g) the details of any financing proposal published on the Private Financing Platform; (h) the criteria and methodology for accepting a PFP Prospect’s financing proposal for publication on a Private Financing Platform; (i) the methodology of, and limitations to, the due diligence undertaken by the PFP Operator concerning each PFP Prospect identified on the Private Financing Platform, in accordance with Rule 18.4.1; (j) the governance and operational arrangements of any Body Corporate used as an intermediary between a PFP Client and any PFP Prospect; (k) the details of the exit facility, if any, that the PFP Operator offers upon the Private Financing Platform, in accordance with Rule 18.8; and (l) any other relevant information concerning the roles or obligations of the PFP Operator that a PFP Client should be aware of.

question: What obligations does a Recognised Investment Exchange have regarding the review of a Price Reporting Agency's compliance with Rule 3.11.2, and what are the specific requirements that the Price Reporting Agency must meet?
answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange is required to have arrangements in place to regularly review whether a Price Reporting Agency continues to meet the requirements of Rule 3.11.2 [#SRC:7728ff1d-b279-4806-b3fd-13f3e8a34e79]. The Price Reporting Agency must adhere to several specific requirements: it must have fair and non-discriminatory procedures for establishing prices of a Financial Instrument, which are made public; demonstrate adequate transparency over its methodology, calculation, and inputs; prioritize concluded transactions where appropriate; maintain a good standing and repute as an independent entity; have a sound corporate governance framework; ensure its staff avoid conflicts of interest that could materially impact price establishment; and have adequate complaint resolution mechanisms [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a].
source_passage_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange must have arrangements in place to regularly review whether a Price Reporting Agency continues to meet the requirements of Rule 3.11.2.
target_passage_text: For the purposes of Rules 3.11.1 and 3.11.3, a Price Reporting Agency must: (a) have fair and non-discriminatory procedures for establishing prices of a Financial Instrument, which are made public; (b) demonstrate adequate and appropriate transparency over the methodology, calculation and inputs to allow users to understand how the benchmark or index is derived and its potential limitations; (c) where appropriate, give priority to concluded transactions in making assessments and adopt measures to minimise selective reporting; (d) be of good standing and repute as an independent and objective price reporting agency or index provider; (e) have a sound corporate governance framework; (f) have adequate arrangements to avoid its staff having any conflicts of interest where such conflicts are, or are likely to have, a material adverse impact on a price establishment process; and (g) adequate complaint resolution mechanisms to resolve any complaints about its assessment process and methodology.

question: What specific information must an Applicant include in their written application to the Regulator to demonstrate compliance with the Remote Member Requirements at the time of application and on an ongoing basis?
answer: An Applicant seeking to become a Remote Member must submit a written application to the Regulator detailing how it satisfies or intends to satisfy the Remote Member Requirements both at the date of the application and on an ongoing basis [#TGT:26fb8042-c784-44c9-84f0-4b7821974a97]. The application must include specific information such as the business or trading name intended for use in the ADGM, the address of the registered and head office in the home jurisdiction, the name of the Recognised Body for which membership is sought, and the name and contact details of the Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator in the home jurisdiction [#SRC:9820bf55-9b39-42c8-8471-04d83bc34f82]. Additionally, the application must explain how the Applicant will meet the Remote Member Requirements as outlined in Rule 8.2.1 [#SRC:9820bf55-9b39-42c8-8471-04d83bc34f82].
source_passage_text: The written application in Rule 8.1.1 is to include: (a) the business name or trading name the Remote Member intends to use in the ADGM; (b) the address of the Remote Members registered office and head office in its home jurisdiction; (c) the name of the Recognised Body upon which it is applying for membership; (d) the name of, and contact details relating to, the Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator in its home jurisdiction; and (e) how the Applicant will satisfy the Remote Member Requirements set out in Rule 8.2.1.
target_passage_text: An Applicant to be a Remote Member must submit a written application to the Regulator on how it satisfies or intends to satisfy the Remote Member Requirements at the date of the application and on an ongoing basis.

question: When should someone be careful not to spread false or misleading information about a Financial Instrument, and what are some ways this information might be shared?
answer: Someone should be careful not to spread false or misleading information about a Financial Instrument when they know or should know that the information is not true [#TGT:69005f53-8e03-4e6f-b2eb-82b1fff946ef]. This information might be shared through various means, such as a Regulatory Announcement Service, media like radio or TV, the internet, market information services, or even verbally [#SRC:0e9ee065-2362-4ded-9316-052189226b32].
source_passage_text: Means of dissemination. The dissemination of information under section 92(6) could, in the Regulator's view, be by a variety of means, including, for example: (a) through a Regulatory Announcement Service; (b) through media such as the radio, a newspaper or television; (c) through the internet, including any form of social media; (d) through any market information service such as a trading terminal; or (e) by conveying information verbally to another person.
target_passage_text: The fifth is where the Behaviour consists of the dissemination of information by any means which gives, or is likely to give, a false or misleading impression as to a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity by a person who knew or could reasonably be expected to have known that the information was false or misleading.

question: What must an Authorised Person include in their Resolution Pack about Client Accounts, and how should these details be organized?
answer: An Authorised Person must include a master list of all Client Accounts in their Resolution Pack, as required by specific rules [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. This list should contain detailed information such as the account name, number, location, bank details, terms and conditions, whether the account is open or closed, and the date it was opened or closed [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d]. This ensures that all necessary details about Client Accounts are systematically recorded and accessible.
source_passage_text: The following records must be included in the Resolution Pack of an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business: (a) Rules 2.7.1 and 3.7.1(d) (records of Client classification and Client agreements); (b) Rules 14.6.2 and 15.4.3 (master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client Money and Client investments); (c) Rule 15.4.4 and Rule 15.4.5 (adequate records and Client's written permission re use of Client Investments); (d) Rules 14.7.1 and 14.7.4 (assessment of appropriateness of Third-Party Agent and acknowledgement by Third-Party agent in respect of Client Money); and (e) Rule 15.5.1 and 15.6.1 (assessment of appropriateness of Third Party Agent and acknowledgement by Third-Party Agent in respect of Client Investments); and (f) Rule 14.11.1 and 15.9.1 (most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments).
target_passage_text: An Authorised Person must maintain a master list of all Client Accounts. The master list must detail: (a) the name of the account; (b) the account number; (c) the location of the account; (d) the bank, its address and contact information; (e) the account terms and conditions; (f) whether the account is currently open or closed; and (g) the date of opening or closure.

question: What must an Authorised Person do about CET1 Capital when they get authorised and after that?
answer: An Authorised Person must ensure that their Common Equity Tier 1 Capital (CET1 Capital) is at least equal to their Base Capital Requirement both when they get authorised and at all times after that [#SRC:ef0be50a-35f4-4cfc-92c5-c7fd6d52a32b]. This requirement applies to all Authorised Persons, no matter their category, and is detailed in Section 3.10 [#TGT:f7a7169f-e5db-4678-9284-868409b88d8a].
source_passage_text: An Authorised Person, whichever Category it is a member of, must hold a minimum amount of CET1 Capital at the time that it obtains authorisation and at all times thereafter, in accordance with Rule 3.3.3, corresponding to the Base Capital Requirement.
target_passage_text: An Authorised Person must have Common Equity Tier 1 Capital (CET1 Capital), as defined in Section 3.10, of not less than its relevant Base Capital Requirement at the time that it obtains authorisation and at all times thereafter.

question: How must an Authorised Person calculate its Credit Risk Capital Requirement, considering the provisions in both Part 3 and Chapter 4 of the Rules?
answer: An Authorised Person is required to calculate its Credit Risk Capital Requirement (CRCOM) by adhering to the applicable Rules outlined in both Part 3 and Chapter 4. The overall Capital Requirement, of which CRCOM is a component, is governed by the Rules in Part 3, specifically Rules 3.5.1 and 3.5.2, and is further supplemented by Appendix 4 [#SRC:c03600d2-2dac-495b-bba4-fe457d5e7166]. Additionally, Chapter 4 provides specific applicable Rules that must be followed for the calculation of CRCOM [#TGT:8b8d4332-205d-4188-b48d-748ecc15479a]. Therefore, compliance with both sections is essential for the accurate calculation of the Credit Risk Capital Requirement.
source_passage_text: The Credit Risk Capital Requirement (also referred to in these Rules as CRCOM) is a component of the calculation of the overall Capital Requirement of an Authorised Person, as provided in Rules 3.5.1 and 3.5.2. The Rules in this Part 3, supplemented by App4, govern the manner of calculation of the CRCOM.
target_passage_text: CRCOM. An Authorised Person must calculate its Credit Risk Capital Requirement in accordance with the applicable Rules in Chapter 4.

question: When can the Regulator change or skip Rule 2.3.2, and what does this have to do with an Applicant's audited financial records?
answer: The Regulator can change or skip Rule 2.3.2 if it believes it's good for investors and they have enough information to make a smart decision about the Issuer and the Shares for the Official List [#SRC:108a7eb5-7dc8-4146-9fbb-d68fe745ccca]. This is connected to the rule that an Applicant must have audited financial records for the past three years or a shorter time if the Regulator agrees, and these records must be consolidated, follow IFRS or other standards the Regulator accepts, and be audited by standards the Regulator approves [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1]. This flexibility helps ensure that investors are protected while allowing for necessary adjustments.
source_passage_text: The Regulator may modify or waive Rule 2.3.2 if it is satisfied that is desirable in the interests of investors and that investors have the necessary information available to arrive at an informed judgement about the Issuer and the Shares for which an admission to the Official List is sought.
target_passage_text: Audited financial statements. An Applicant must have published or filed audited accounts which: (1) cover a prior period of three years or any other, shorter period acceptable to the Regulator; (2) are consolidated for the Applicant and any of its subsidiary undertakings; (3) have been prepared in accordance with IFRS or other standards acceptable to the Regulator; and (4) have been audited and reported on by auditors in accordance with auditing standards of the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB) or other standards acceptable to the Regulator.

question: Under what conditions may the Regulator waive or modify Rule 2.3.8 concerning the transfer of Shares, and how does this relate to the requirement for an Applicant's Securities to be freely transferable for admission to the Official List?
answer: The Regulator may waive or modify Rule 2.3.8 in exceptional circumstances if the Applicant has the power to disapprove the transfer of Shares, provided the Regulator is satisfied that this power would not disturb the market in those Shares [#SRC:7b5a94d4-4228-4d1a-b46a-d9f9dab0d14d]. This is relevant to the requirement for an Applicant's Securities to be admitted to the Official List, as they must be freely transferable [#TGT:bd978059-6701-4512-8a39-1f9364110d3a]. The waiver or modification by the Regulator would need to ensure that any restriction on transfer does not affect the market stability or the free transferability requirement.
source_passage_text: The Regulator may, in exceptional circumstances, waive or modify Rule 2.3.8 where the Applicant has the power to disapprove the transfer of Shares, if the Regulator is satisfied that this power would not disturb the market in those Shares.
target_passage_text: Validity and transferability. To be admitted to the Official List, an Applicant's Securities must: (1) be duly authorised according to the requirements of the Applicant's constitution; (2) have any necessary statutory or other consents; (3) be freely transferable; and (4) in the case of Shares, be fully paid and free from any liens and from any restrictions on the right of transfer.

question: What are the disclosure requirements for a Mining Reporting Entity when the forecast financial information is derived from a Production Target, and how should commercially sensitive material economic assumptions be handled?
answer: A Mining Reporting Entity must disclose all material economic assumptions used to determine forecast financial information, including any that are considered commercially sensitive, by providing a statement and an explanation of the methodology used to determine these assumptions [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. Additionally, the disclosure must include the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, which may relate to either the Mining Reporting Entity's Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or material Mining Project(s) [#TGT:3b6fe7a5-ba91-4bcf-b1f3-f46b7164fe1d].
source_passage_text: A Mining Reporting Entitys disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include: (1) in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information: (a) all material economic assumptions employed; (b) if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and Guidance A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure. (c) all other material assumptions utilised. (2) the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_passage_text: Forecast financial information derived from a Production Target may be disclosed in relation to either a Mining Reporting Entity’s: (1) Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings; or (2) material Mining Project(s).

question: When an Authorised Person is calculating E* for pre-settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs under a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, what methods must be used to determine the appropriate haircuts, and how does this relate to the calculation of the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount?
answer: An Authorised Person must calculate E* for pre-settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs that are covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement by applying either standard supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts [#TGT:19b5846d-b958-4e12-a8d2-ffe1b2dd7ed8]. This calculation is necessary when the Authorised Person is using the FCCA and has taken eligible financial Collateral for the SFT [#SRC:56e2cb44-f613-4f2a-bd4c-8726a79a5776]. The calculated E* must then be substituted for E when determining the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for its CR Exposures to that Counterparty, in accordance with Rules A4.3.2 to A4.3.6 in App4 [#SRC:56e2cb44-f613-4f2a-bd4c-8726a79a5776].
source_passage_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT that is covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and using the FCCA, must calculate E* for all its CR Exposures to any single Counterparty covered by the qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, in accordance with Rules A4.3.2 to A4.3.6 in App4 (if the Authorised Person is using supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts), and substitute E* for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for its CR Exposures to that Counterparty under Section 4.8.
target_passage_text: Calculation of E* for collateralised transactions other than OTC Derivative transactions and long settlement transactions. An Authorised Person must calculate the appropriate haircuts to be applied using one of the following methods: (a) standard supervisory haircuts; or (b) own estimate haircuts.
